movie_review_blurb: Stallone and Russell play well off each other, and with Palance lurking in the background, this buddy-breakout never loses its way.
Unnecessarily complex in parts, Constantine still delivers a supernatural wallop, fueling a never-ending fascination with what lies beyond our world.
Will Smith finally makes the leap into romantic comedies with the delightful if somewhat predictable Hitch. Will, baby, what took you so long?
The not-too-frightening, plodding Boogeyman proves that major Hollywood studios like to dump all their stinkers at the beginning of the year.
My Best Friend's Picture Perfect Wedding, er, I mean The Wedding Date...is surprisingly engaging--mostly...
Even though Hide and Seek's chilling tag phrase--"Come out, come out, wherever you are!"--may be enticing, just stay right where you are.
The title sort of says it all. Even though is it a rehash, Assault on Precinct 13 still assaults your senses and keeps you on the edge of your seat.
Racing Stripes is pretty standard family fare without too many charming moments.
Like a big glass of milk and a slice of apple pie, Because of Winn-Dixie is just as wholesome as it gets, if you don't mind overdosing on the sugar once in awhile.
In Good Company astonishes you in a quietly sublime way.
The sequel is pretty much what you'd expect--mindless fluff with maybe a little less calamity than its predecessor, but a lot more schmaltz. Oy vey!
Spanglish may not necessarily be up to James L. Brooks' usual Oscar-caliber standards, but its still an enjoyable movie full of poignant moments.
The film is just too smart and twisty for its own good.
Blade: Trinity is by far the worst of the Blade movies, but for diehard fans of the comic book, it still may hold some excitement.
Closer gets about as close as it gets to showing how love sometimes makes people do awful things to each other.
If Christmas means spending it with the irascible, over-the-top Kranks, then taking a Caribbean cruise really does sound like a much better deal.
If you have a seriously disturbed affinity for talking sink utensils, then SpongeBob will totally tickle your fancy.
...the trite film fails to deliver the necessary thrills and chills it so desperately wants us to experience.
...Pull out your pirate swords, dust off your fairy wings and clap your hands if you believe!
If not for the larger-than-life multitasking by Tyler Perry, Diary of a Mad Black Woman would be just another tedious, over-the-top movie about self-discovery.
movie_title: Diary of a Mad Black Woman (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The Jacket is a horrifyingly strange and cluttered but innately fascinating movie-going experience, especially with Adrien Brody's layered performance at the helm.
With Will Ferrell infusing his comic brilliance into the proceedings, at least you know you won't be dragged out of the theater Kicking & Screaming.
The run-of-the-mill comedy might not be the Monster hit Jennifer Lopez is seeking, but it opens up the possibility of seeing more of the talented Jane Fonda.
Every once in a while you need a movie like this to come crashing down on you.
If the intriguing but ultimately derivative Kingdom of Heaven had arrived before these recent period epics, it may have stood a better chance of enthralling us.
With Ice Cube at the wheel, it delivers all the adrenaline a junkie could ever want. Just don't pay too much attention to anything else going on in the movie.
Needless to say, as a cringe-worthy and excruciatingly awful comedy, you shouldn't pay a dime of King's Ransom.
Despite strong performances from Nicole Kidman and Sean Penn, The Interpreter unfortunately doesn't quite translate into a compelling sociopolitical thriller.
Following in the footsteps of the Arnolds and the Sylvesters before him, Vin Diesel pulls off a nice comic performance in the otherwise gushy The Pacifier.
OK, I admit it: movies about demonic houses scare me a little. I mean, we've all, at one time or another, stared long and hard at the attic and/or basement door, haven't we?
Despite Queen Latifah and its boisterous cast's best efforts to style the perfect social comedy, Beauty Shop doesn't quite cut it.
Although Sandra Bullock is entirely watchable, Miss Congeniality 2 fails to win the title the second time around. Say goodnight, Gracie.
The Mouse House factory churns out more cute with Ice Princess...you may have to go get our teeth checked for fear of getting cavities from all the syrupy sweetness.
Everyone really wants The Ring Two to be as frightening as the original. But unfortunately, the deadly videotape does not hold up to repeat viewings.
It starts as a tensely twist-filled action thriller, but through some serious missteps in logic and clichéd moments, it ends in a bloody mess.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
They can do it. Peter and Bobby Farrelly can actually make a movie that doesn't include one fart joke. Wow.
If you can use Jedi mind tricks to gloss over the trite dialogue and stiff acting, Revenge of the Sith is going to give you the big payoff you've been waiting for.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Lacking a human touch here and there, The Polar Express is still a brilliant effort in CGI-animation and will certainly evoke the Christmas spirit in us all.
The Incredibles eventually captures all the right emotional beats, thumping superhero action and poignant moments to make the film, well, almost incredible.
Director Jean-Jacques Annaud has done it again--a film that delights, saddens, gives hope and fully captures the spirit of the majestic tiger.
If not for some inspired moments of breathtaking beauty and heartfelt performances, it would just be one of those tired love stories that you quickly forget.
Around the World in 80 Days is like eating a candy bar--loaded with empty calories but also light and fluffy with a sweet Jackie Chan in the center.
The Stepford Wives may not be as perfect as Stepford's manufactured denizens but, supported by a fabulous cast, it produces some genuine belly laughs just the same.
Better just to keep this fat cat suctioned to the car window.
With a little help from the sunny Kate Hudson and her kids, at least some of that hokey sentiment gets through and touches your heart. [sniff] Pass the Kleenex, please.
Shrek 2 may not be as fresh and new as the original, but you still can't stop yourself from lovin' the big green ogre anyway.
Spidey and gang are back in Spider-Man 2--perhaps in need of some therapy--but ultimately bigger and better than ever.
Greedy kings, lusty virgins, buff heroes, a cast of thousands, huge battle sequences and a face that "launched a thousand ships"--Troy has it all and then some.
Even with a bevy of talented people and a funny premise, the stinky Envy quickly "Vapoorize"s into thin air
Maybe the film should be called Man on Fire Whose Bleeding Gunshot Wounds Won't Stop Him.
Although it may take its cue from other gender-benders, it's definitely snaps all around for the delightful and heartfelt Connie and Carla.
It's the MTV, Teen Beat-lovin' teenage girls who will sing its praises the loudest.
Risky Business doesn't need a remake, and even if it did, The Girl Next Door is an unoriginal attempt, despite its modern-day spin.
...More than a few discouraging words could be said about its dull animation. The once-great Mouse House needs to keep up with the Joneses.
Quote not available.
For the love of all that's unholy, drive a wooden stake, shoot a silver bullet, do whatever it takes to put Van Helsing out of its misery.
"What's it all about, Alfie?" Unfortunately, in this mediocre remake of the 1966 original, not a whole lot.
Although a sequel may not have been entirely necessary, Before Sunset does provide some closure...
Besides adolescent girls who either want to be Hilary Duff or want to slobber over Chad Michael Murray, the story offers nothing new to an already beaten-to-death teen genre.
Wow. Foxx's portrait of the man, the myth, the legend is nothing short of remarkable, a tour de force.
With the skillfully framed, beautifully written, delicately acted Sideways, Alexander Payne may just have found his golden ticket to Oscar glory.
If anyone needs to survive anything, it's having to sit through this dreadfully unfunny holiday movie. Pin a medal on me.
Shall We Dance? never seems to rise above its syrupy premise and ballroom antics.
while belly laughing and scratching your head at the same time, Huckabees will wash over you in the sweetest way, leaving you wholly satisfied with the outcome.
The uproarious Shark Tale is sure to please fish-lovin' masses, but it might have benefited from a little Pixar fairy dust to make it more complete.
The Forgotten just doesn't quite hold up as either a gut-wrenching tale of loss or a convincing psychological thriller.
Even though it feels the need to lapse into juvenile clowning around every once in awhile, Anchorman is still gonna make you laugh--hard.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: As far as baseball movies go, Mr. 3000 may not be considered a classic, but...it'll still get you to sing "Take Me Out to the Ball Game."
Wicker Park, a deeply psychological story about love and obsession, is really a hard film to pin down--but refreshingly enough, that's a good thing
Even though it's a valiant effort, Vanity Fair just lacks the necessary talent and oomph to propel it to the level of an elegant, entertaining English period piece.
You know exactly what you're getting into when you sit down to watch a movie in which there is not only one but many giant super snakes...Please tell me you know.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It delivers the same bland adolescent fluff and feel-good family values its predecessor provided...This could get interesting--but it doesn't, not really.
Collateral is an ultimate thrill ride through the mean streets of L.A., powered by a killer performance (pun intended) from Tom Cruise.
As a self-proclaimed shark-movie junkie, Open Water brilliantly taps into that ultimate fear of what lurks down below.
While The Village may not ultimately be considered one of Shyamalan's best efforts...it still bears his unique mark for understanding the human condition.
...you imagine yourself as Alice, blowing away zombies and biochemical mutants, all while dexterously maneuvering your thumbs on your PlayStation controller.
As a thriller, Spartan will hold your attention, but unfortunately writer/director's David Mamet's style doesn't fit well in this milieu.
When Adam Sandler throws a long hilarious, no-brainer comedy of a pass into the end zone, you know we are going to be there to catch it.
Honestly, how can you not root for a movie about a Depression-era underdog prizefighter who beats the odds and wins it big? It seems anti-American or something.
Annapolis isn't anything but an over-boiled, corn-fed version of An Officer and a Gentleman.
As far as movies about enchanting nannies go, Mary Poppins is certainly the classic favorite. But the delightfully quirky and heartwarming Nanny McPhee could be a close second.
A war between vampires and werewolves was sort of cool once. But twice?

Tristan & Isolde strives to be the good old-fashioned medieval kind of romance that stirs the soul. But due to the somewhat lackluster performances from the doomed young lovers, the film doesn't quite hit the mark.
Without Queen Latifah, Last Holiday would have been a somewhat tedious vacation, despite its beautiful setting.
Hoodwinked is CSI meets the Brother Grimm. But as clever as its premise is, the animated feature can't quite maintain its wily sense of humor.

Grandma's Boy combines pot-smoking, big breasts, African bushmen, octogenarians, video-gaming techno-geeks--and one inappropriate masturbation scene--in one feel-good movie perfect for teenage boys. If they can get in, that is.
This latest horror remake may not necessarily pack the same horrifying wallop as the original, but When a Stranger Calls is still a classic example of a babysitter's worst nightmare.
Some say Match Point marks writer/director Woody Allen's return to excellence. Maybe so, but it's really more of a reminder on how deliciously screwed up he can be.
Here's a rumor for ya: this is pretty bland stuff, despite all the clever people involved and good intentions to pull off a hip dramedy. Ultimately, Rumor Has It doesn't know what it wants to be.
Perhaps a tad long-winded, Steven Spielberg's Munich is a still a well-crafted, superbly acted film...let's just say, it'll get you talking.
As one of the more likable holiday films to come around in a long time, the comedy The Family Stone will also surprise you with its depth and emotional appeal.

Sure, The Producers, a movie-turned-hit Broadway musical-turned-movie again is pure camp, filled with over-blown musical numbers and over-inflated performances. But that's what we want in a movie musical--unadulterated fun.

The Chronicles of Narnia does indeed capture a certain wondrous, fantastical imagination inspired by C.S. Lewis' literary classics. But the film unfortunately also suffers from Lord of the Rings envy.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: An epic romantic period piece with deeply felt performances, beautiful costumes and exquisitely framed sets, Geisha pretty much defines the phrase "Oscar contender."
The delightfully off-centered Transamerica is one those juicy little character pieces that allows Felicity Huffman to turn in an unbelievably gutsy, Oscar-worthy performance.
Tommy Lee Jones' stirring and deeply felt Three Burials proves one thing: Sometimes the most compelling films are the ones closest to the heart.
movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Family dysfunctions, spellings bees, spiritual enlightenment--Bee Season definitely has an odd lot of things going on. But this family drama somehow draws you into its weird little realm and holds you there.

The title is deceptive; there's nothing new in Something New. In fact, it's a pretty standard Waiting to Exhale-ish dramedy. Still, the sweet and engaging chemistry between the two leads manages to draw you in.
A Kleenex-producing tale of survival and friendship that may just make you grab your favorite pooch and promise you'll never leave him/her stranded in the frozen wastelands.
Akeelah musters up all the excitement it can about an underdog from the 'hood spelling impossibly difficult words. Formulaic, yes, but an admirable effort.
Be prepared. United 93 is overwhelming, telling a story we've all come to know so very well. It will be one of the most affecting movies you'll ever see--if you can bring yourself to see it, that is.
While this latest video game adaptation will most likely thrill its legions of fans with its graphic demonic depictions, the overblown plot deters the film from being a true fright fest.
OK, so American Dreamz tries a little too hard to be satirically witty and bitingly political. But, darn it, it still makes you laugh in spite of yourself.
Maybe they should have titled the hackneyed Take the Lead something like Shall We Dance...in Detention?
This crafty indie with a big-budget cast goes from a seemingly paint-by-numbers noirish comic thriller to something entirely more genre-bending. Definitely a ride worth taking.
How nice it is to see the whole Ice Age gang back, but unfortunately, this sequel falls under the "cute-but-not-quite-as-good-as-the-original" category.
Curious George is an adorable and heartening adaptation that does the classic children's tale justice.
Like a breath of fresh air, Thank You for Smoking takes an unapologetic and satirical swipe at the establishment; no one is left unscathed.
Hallelujah! Spike Lee is back to his old tricks with Inside Man, his own quirky vision of a classic heist movie, complete with that certain Big Apple flair.
Failure to Launch thankfully doesn't live up to its title. Bolstered by some quirky performances, it actually takes off in a surprisingly engaging way.
A little bit Splash, a little bit Nickelodeon, Aquamarine is just as sweet as gummy worm bait and is guaranteed to reel in the middle school set who are itching to do something at the mall.
Oh, no, there's nothing formulaic about 16 Blocks, not at all.
Doogal tries to be part of the hip CGI-animated club, with all the pop-culture references and feel-good messages. But unfortunately, it fails on all levels.

Running Scared is filled with plenty of blood-splattering violence, profanity, sexual perversions, and whatever other deviant behavior you can think of. What it doesn't have is any cohesiveness or finesse.
Freedomland is an overblown drama that leads nowhere, despite its fervent attempts at hard-hitting social commentary.
The Shaggy Dog, another tired retread from Disney, is so aggressively unfunny it should just roll over and play dead. Come on, guys, do something original for once.
Forget Jeff Corwin. Forget the Crocodile Hunter. Animal Planet needs to develop a show for Alex, the lion, and his four-legged monochromatic friends.
Despite a few bone-tickling moments, the romantic comedy Just Friends is, well, just OK.
Although it is indeed an entertaining and noble attempt to bring the hugely popular Broadway musica Rent to the big screen, something is unfortunately lost in the translation.
If it's hardcore, blood-spattered vengeance you want, Four Brothers the summer movie for you.
This foolhardy Hazzard upgrade may be appealing to its TV fans. Or it could just remind you how ridiculous it was the show ran for six seasons in the first place.
The undeniably superior Hustle & Flow is this year's indie darling--it should garner some Oscar attention, especially for the captivating Terrence Howard.
It doesn't make a lick of sense, of course, but we don't care. This is the real Attack of the Clones, baby!
Although it's hard to top Walter Matthau's irascible original, casting Thornton as the baseball-pelting, beer-swillin' yet lovable curmudgeon is kind of a no-brainer.
Coming from the fertile and creative mind of Tim Burton, it is still a marvelous confectionary delight, especially to those who like a darker chocolate.
The Frat Pack-filled Wedding Crashers is one of the funniest R-rated movies to come around in a long time.
There is absolutely no reason on God's green earth a second Deuce should ever exist.
Although the film portends to be a creepy ghost story, you'll more than likely be bored to tears, which, of course, will be lost in all the icky water gushing everywhere.
With the power of Spielberg and Cruise behind it, the sinister and tense War of the Worlds is this summer's blockbuster to beat them all.
Land of the Dead is just a giant excuse to see the walking dead pigging out on human flesh--in all its blood-dripping, bone-crunching, brain-slurping fashion. Yuck.
Watching Nicole Kidman fly around on a broom is one thing, but if you're looking for a little renewed magic, Bewitched unfortunately isn't it.
You'll most likely want to throw up and call it a night after swallowing this big ball of cotton candy.
...don't expect any spousal abuse in the mushy, pedestrian and totally unnecessary big-screen version of The Honeymooners.
Bring the spouse and live vicariously.
Quote not available.
It's getting more than a little tiresome sitting through sport movies revolving around a team of under-aged underdogs and their curmudgeonly coach.

The exhilarating Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire takes the best parts of J.K. Rowling's fourth installment and serves them up in one heck of an action-packed, albeit darker, film. Parents, be forewarned--this isn't kid's stuff anymore.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Wes Craven turns in a tightly wound roller-coaster ride. Intellectually, you know it's improbable, but you can't help but raise your hands when the big drop comes.
The Constant Gardener is a masterful mixture of suspense, Third World strife and a heartfelt love story for the ages.
It's true Jane Austen's lush and romantic Pride and Prejudice has been adapted too many times to count, but this latest film version can take pride in being one of the best.
Tagged as a "new adventure from the world of Jumanji," Zathura certainly keeps to the same venturesome spirit as the original. But the sequel still seems to be a bit of a retread.
...some may be disappointed Jarhead isn't a typical war movie. But make no mistake, the film is about war--and it'll still get under your skin.
Prime is a somewhat enjoyable look at a budding, albeit complicated, romance. But it tends to take itself a tad too seriously.
Part thriller, part mind-bending absurdity, it will definitely leave you scratching your head. But try to stay until the end--it might make up for the rest of it.
As yet another underdog/family flick that tugs mercilessly at our heart strings, it just doesn't offer anything new and exciting in this well-worn genre.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Domino is definitely muddled and too hip for its own good. But the true story behind Domino Harvey's life is a fascinating character study nonetheless.
In this summer of raunchy, hilarious R-rated comedies, Virgin fits right in--even if the one-joke premise gets a little stale towards the end.
With winning performances, fancy camerawork and a classic root-for-the-little-guy scenario, Greatest Game tees off with the best of them.
Roman Polanski's Oliver Twist is probably the most faithful adaptation. But hardly anyone will take notice; it's just a tale that's been told too many times before.
Flightplan might not necessary execute the cleverest of landings, but with Jodie Foster onboard, you know it'll at least have an excellent takeoff.
Proof proves you can watch a flick about depressed, schizophrenic people concocting complicated math equations and still enjoy it. I swear!
Corpse Bride is a wild, vibrant and somewhat romantically morbid trip through the afterlife.
A green-screen mess without much rumble.
It does feel a bit like a TV movie of the week, but the strong performances elevate it to another level.
Quote not available.
Into the Blue is just dumb fun in the sun.
The franchise serves only one purpose: To show Tom Cruise donning disguises, dangling precariously and blowing stuff up. In that regards, M:i III succeeds.
Unfortunately, Taking Lives doesn't add any brilliance to the exhausted spot-the-serial-killer psychological thriller, but get props for a clever ending.
Starsky & Hutch will remind you just how bad '70s cop shows could be, but its stellar comic cast will keep you laughing in spite of it.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
It would be cheaper to try and catch the trailer while watching another movie worth the price.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Eddie Murphy tries to be the suave hero type again, and because of a very weak storyline, he doesn't really succeed.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Spy Kids 2: The Island of Lost Dreams (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Taking the universal idea of the possibility of life on other planets, but exploring it only within the microcosm of this one rural family, is a brilliant ploy. And throughout the film, there is one underlying theme -- faith.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Mothman is too slowly paced, taking its interminable sweet time getting to the punch, which actually is pretty powerful. You just wished it happened about a half hour earlier.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Fueled by a wonderful performance from Leonardo DiCaprio, Catch Me If You Can is a lighthearted yet heart-wrenching look at the making of a truly brilliant, if somewhat reluctant, con artist.
Disney's Treasure Planet adds a unique spin to a classic story which has delighted readers for generations.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
A gritty and epic history lesson about one of the most notorious cities in the world--you may have to take notes for the test afterwards.
The film's crowning glory remains the battle at Helm's Deep and can best be described as Braveheart meets The Alamo; it'll keep your heart leaping into your throat at every turn.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Look for it to gather a few accolades in the coming award season.
You still should see it for the performances, even if you cringe at what they have to say.
Quote not available.

The worst of the movie's offenses, however, happens in the editing room. With all the good guys, bad guys, skiing, helicopters and running through snow you're never quite sure who's who or what's what.
No matter how ridiculous and inconsistent Shanghai Knights gets, marveling at Chan's acrobatics and laughing at Wilson's sardonic one-liners is still worth the price of admission.

For a ringside seat at the secret CIA training process, The Recruit delivers a somewhat fascinating view. Yet, if not powered by Colin Farrell's strong performance, the predictable film would ultimately fall flat on its face.
Make no mistake about it. Kangaroo Jack is a movie that will appeal to a very limited audience--boys 8 to 12. If you don't fall into this category, don't waste your time.
A Guy Thing is just about as predictable a romantic comedy as you can get, save for a few laughs here and there. Unless you're hard-up for something to see or perhaps on a first date, give it a pass.
About Schmidt is a curious slice of Americana...the characters are so clearly drawn and the dialogue so rich, you are immediately hooked.
One thing has been made very clear -- Being John Malkovich wasn't a fluke.
The film has the age group 16-24 written all over it. But come on, folks, even good intentions to capture a certain market can't make up for a downright silly movie.
The one thing you can say about this sequel is that it tries too hard to be like its ultra-hip predecessor.
Lopez doesn't do anything out of the ordinary. In fact, it looks like she may have simply cloned the same expressions she put on in her other successful romantic comedy, The Wedding Planner.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
This is a pleasant, sometimes very funny film which manages to explore some interesting topics.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
The film is a pure gem, proving once again what an incredible visionary Spielberg truly is.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Rings is a breathtaking piece of filmmaking.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Quite possibly could be the best thing Ron Howard has ever directed.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
It's a franchise that should keep going.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Maybe someday, just once, a Disney animated film will surprise us.
Quote not available.
Even without a twist or two, this compelling psychological thriller delivers the goods.
In a cast of many, the film is chock-full of wonderful performances, but it's the matured Ya-Yas who steal the show.
movie_title: Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Co-directors, co-writers and brothers Paul and Chris Weitz deftly handle the material and find an hysterical but poignant way of telling the story.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Leave it to the Farrelly brothers to once again gross us out.
Quote not available.
Charlie Kaufman has succinctly combined his innate quirkiness with his intuitive imagination to create one of the more ingenious yet simplistic love stories ever written.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets surpasses Sorcerer's Stone as a crisper, more action-packed film, which will more than thrill the billions of Harry Potter fans everywhere.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Finally, a delightful piece of Christmas fluff to chase away visions of chainsaw-wielding serial killers.
As much as Meg Ryan wants to win an Academy Award, unfortunately, she doesn't make the cut.
Brother Bear should please most kids, but its formulaic story and predictable animation prove Disney needs to try a little harder next time.
The title really says it all: The Human Stain is only an imprint rather than a cohesive film. Read the novel instead to get the whole picture.
Even though Beyond Borders certainly isn't the greatest love story ever told, the film still offers a plethora of fascinating, war-torn landscapes--and may inspire you to volunteer for the UN.
You think a jury is chosen to give a fair and impartial verdict? Think again. Runaway Jury turns that particularly lofty civic duty on its ear.
Despite dragging a little, Mystic River is worth its weight in what will certainly be Oscar gold.
Master and Commander creates a painstakingly accurate picture of life on a 1800s warship. Even when things are dead calm, it's a breathtaking film to behold.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: ...One of those little films you remember in a big way.
Duplex isn't very complicated, thank goodness, but makes sure to spread a requisite amount of mean-spiritedness.
Cold Creek Manor is one of those cases of the trailer making it look a whole lot scarier than it actually is.
It's about time someone gave Bill Murray a leading juicy role the talented actor could sink his teeth into.
With an excellent cast and expert direction, Matchstick Men just may con you into having a rollicking good time. The bonus is you won't mind being "taken" at all.
If you ever wonder what happened to those child stars of the '70s and '80s, Dickie Roberts sheds some light, but it doesn't make you necessarily laugh as hard as it intends to
In what universe does a New York Jewish socialite and a hardcore, streetwise rapper sound like a good pairing for a romantic comedy?
Jackie Chan has just as much fun in The Medallion as he does in any of his other films--but he doesn't need the overworked special effects used in it to accentuate his extraordinary talents.
Even though it portends to be full of twists and turns, you're really not going to be terribly surprised by what goes on in Out of Time.
Quote not available.
Back in Action misses out on a brilliant opportunity to tell a simple story about a rabbit vs. a duck.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: You'll find the hokey material in Havana Nights strangely familiar, but it doesn't matter.
Supported by Lindsay Lohan's effervescent performance, Drama Queen has a fun flair for the dramatics but ultimately is a piece of fluff targeted to a limited audience.
movie_title: Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Even though it's populated with juvenile antics, 50 First Dates is still a great date movie, cliched as that sounds.
The only thing to "catch" in this film is perhaps a cold--from sitting in the theater with the 'tweener set.
Despite its been-there, done-that theme, Miracle stirs your emotions anyway...
If we were to give The Perfect Score a SAT score, it would be a 1040--it doesn't pass with flying colors, but it bubbles in a few choice moments.
A film whose dice are loaded with a slew of great performances, a nearly flawless character study of the unlucky who find love in a place called Vegas, baby.
Quote not available.
Win a Date... has enough appeal and good-natured wit to overcome its inherent flaws and charm the pants off any hopeless romantic.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Chasing Liberty should have been called "How To Deal with Chasing Liberty While Remembering To Walk."
Quote not available.
People may love those Disney films for those cutesy, catchy songs, but Peter Pan really is a good story. Heck, it's a great story. But it's just been done.
With a sweeping narrative, mind-blowing battle sequences and gut-wrenching performances, could there be a grander finale to a classic epic? Not in this millennium.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Except for a few bright moments with its cast, Stuck on You doesn't stick with you in any way other than to remind you the Farrelly brothers have lost their touch.
Although the story and Tom Cruise's performance lack punch, The Last Samurai makes up for its shortcomings in its grand scope...
Although The Haunted Mansion starts promisingly and presents a wealth of possibilities, filmmakers decide to go the formulaic route to bring in the kiddies.
Disney's Teacher's Pet tries hard to be a musical in the form of a quirky animated kid's movie, but ultimately it can't get past the inanity of it all.
Only the last action sequence seems too far off-base from reality even for a Bond movie. I say that intellectually, but it still keeps you on the edge of your seat, watching. You can't help it.
Oh, c'mon, Grind is mindless fun most of the time and if you pretend for a moment you're about 12-15 years old, its totally awesome!
Even with a pedigree of talented actors and filmmakers behind it, Le Divorce's bland, disjointed formula falls far short of expectations.
Quote not available.
It's worth the risk of looking silly in the 3D glasses to join James Cameron on his trip to depths of the North Atlantic for a firsthand look at the great, tragic Titanic.
If it weren't for Chow Yun-Fat, Bulletproof Monk would be shooting blanks.
Granted, Adam Sandler and Jack Nicholson do not disappoint. But despite all the hype about Anger Management, you unfortunately walk away feeling only mildly amused.
Powered by a hard-hitting performance from Colin Farrell, Phone Booth will keep you riveted to your seat--and make you turn that darn cell phone off, for a little while at least.
What a Girl Wants may make you reminisce about your own father-child relationship. It's just sitting through the rest of the teenage girlie stuff that is a little hard to take.
Unfortunately, keeping Kattan in the forefront is also one of the main problems with the film.
Just when you think Identity is just another typical thriller, its original twist hits you on the head, leaving you spinning.
With Head of State, Chris Rock and Bernie Mac give audiences a much-needed excuse to poke fun at--but also admire--the way U.S. democracy is supposed to work.
Thanks to strong performances from its main characters, Dreamcatcher initially catches your attention, but just when it should be at its scariest, it falls apart.
The Hunted could also be called Fun Things To Do With a Knife.
Stay far away from the three hour-plus Gods and Generals--unless, of course, you need a good nap.
It's a broad comedy, pure and simple, but in making us laugh, apparently it is also necessary to insult our intelligence.
It doesn't matter if "Cradle 2 the Grave" offers very little in the form of an engaging story. The daredevil sequences, with the ultra-cool Jet Li at the helm, is a wild trip anyway.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Piglet's Big Movie is a delightfully entertaining film for young children--showing them that even smallest person can be the big hero.
Kevin Costner's Open Range only proves it's time for this cowboy to hang up his spurs.
Lead by a confident cast, Confidence gives yet another entertaining view of the wonderful world of con artists
In The Shape of Things, writer/director Neil Labute molds another whopper of a tale about modern romance--but its hardly a "date" movie.
Gigli is a traffic accident you can't keep your eyes off of. If you have a taste for morbid curiosity, go see it.
Ready for more fun with kid spies Juni and Carmen Cortez? Hope so, because they're back, and this time in 3-D.
Although you may have to sit through some melodramatic moments and you know ultimately how Seabiscuit turns out, don't worry. Sit back, learn a little history and enjoy a great ride.
Nowhere near being extraordinary.
A truly inspiring film.
Although Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas may not necessarily have that certain Pixar cleverness for adults, it provides more than enough good old-fashioned entertainment for the family.
movie_title: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Undeniably, Charlie's Angels: Full Throttle is an enjoyably crazy ride--just make sure to leave your disbelief suspended at the door.
X2: X-Men United is a thoroughly intriguing sequel in the X-Men series, a pure adrenaline ride. But with a weighty--and very important--message attached, the film also makes you think.
Alex & Emma could have been a contender, instead of a drag, which it is.
Nickelodeon's Rugrats and The Wild Thornberrys should learn one thing from their combined effort, Rugrats Go Wild: stick to your own kind.
Just when you thought they couldn't possibly do it again, the guys at Pixar bat it out of the park with Finding Nemo.
Quote not available.
A.I. is a different kind of Spielberg film, and some audiences may not be ready for it.
Even with all its predictability, Bruce Almighty and its star Jim Carrey still leaves you crying from laughter.
If you want to experience nostalgia, rent Pillow Talk--it does a much better job.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Holes, Because of Winn-Dixie and now, Hoot. Since we don't really have after school TV specials anymore, these kid novels-turned-hokey movies seem to be fitting the bill.
Gripping? Gut wrenching? Sure, but if you've seen one high school football movie, especially one set in Texas, you've seen them all.
Just look at little Lindsay Lohan, all grows up, doing romantic comedy like a big girl. It's just a shame Just My Luck is just too inane for words.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Spider-Man is funny, poignant and true to form with Tobey Maguire and company fleshing out the famed comic-book characters with aplomb.

Pixar's latest visual stunner with a heart of gold honors our obsession with the automobile. Although it will make many nostalgic for the open road, especially the historic Route 66, the kids might get a little bored with this one.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Stick with the premise. The idea behind All About Steve has some potential, but then it slides off into hokey-ville.
Disney's Pixar has done it again with the delightful Monsters, Inc.--so sit back, bring the whole family and have a wonderful time.
Extract yourself from your couch and go see this agreeable working class comedy.
Revel in the Glourious-ness that is Inglourious Basterds, writer/director Quentin Tarantino's marvelously skewed take on WWII.
Don't expect The Notebook.
Believe the hype. As a sci-fi thrill ride, and a provocative commentary on xenophobia, District 9 is definitely all that it's cracked up to be.
Prepare to be pleasantly surprised by A Perfect Getaway, a compact, no frills thriller that does it's job nicely.
Don't go see Julie & Julia, a delightful culinary treat, on an empty stomach %u2013 unless, of course, you are a masochist.
Get ready to have your Funny bone tickled, doused in sentiment and then, tickled again.
Blame it on Alvin and the Chipmunks. Cute, furry, and talking, CGI rodents are apparently now the rage, much to the chagrin of anyone over 12.
Applaud a great short film when you see one. Examining the sometimes painful consequences of childbirth, One Love is a well-crafted 15-minute movie that leaves you wanting more.
Don't be afraid. Horror movies about creepy kids can be frightening %u2013 just not in Orphan.
Quote not available.
Retitled this to I Know What You Did at That Sorority Party with That Tire Iron.
Take a real-life story like The Blind Side, which on the surface sounds pretty sappy, and turn it into something honest, heartfelt and surprisingly inspirational.

Combine the late Roald Dahl's clever storytelling, director Wes Anderson's cinematic sensibilities and an engaging vocal cast and you've got the animated Fantastic Mr. Fox, one quirky, dangerous, sweet and entirely entertaining flick.
Throw in bits and pieces from all other disaster movies, up the global destruction ante, turn on the waterworks (literally and figuratively) and you've got 2012.
Take a wonderfully farcical premise based on fact and turn it into a mostly entertaining, sometimes sluggish film about Men playing preposterous war games %u2013 with their minds.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Hold onto your mug of warm apple cider. This newest, action-packed version of A Christmas Carol could get a little bumpy.
A review from a true fan, and from the heart
Whoa nelly, this is about the most frightening movie I've seen in a long time.
Imagine the Terminator series done with sock puppets. 9 isn't necessarily an original story, but the detailed visuals are incredibly creative
While Cirque du Freak: A Vampire's Assistant might hold a certain charm for tween fans, it suffers from too much exposition and not enough freakishly cool vampire action.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Although it has its moments, Couples Retreat isn't so much a movie but rather a giant excuse for some real-life BFFs to hang out in South Pacific.
Drew Barrymore finds the perfect project for her directorial debut, infusing the roller derby fun-fest with her spunk and joie de vivre.
Laugh your ass off. As a cleverly executed horror comedy, Zombieland will keep you in stitches, even as the zombies are trying to rip you apart.
Throw away the Blackberry? Surrogates is yet another serviceable sci-fi whodunit about how our dependency on technology will be the ruin of us all.

Love him or hate him, Michael Moore makes us think; he makes us talk. And if you agree with what he has to say, especially with his latest opus Capitalism: A Love Story, he can inspire you to make a difference.
Enjoy some quirk with your blood splatter. While certainly not the most innovative of horror comedy flicks, Jennifer's Body still has some pizazz, thanks to Diablo Cody's pen.
Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs is a thoroughly delightful and hilarious 3-D animated comedy that'll definitely get you craving giant pancakes, gummi bears and yes, said meat.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Let's pronounce Spike Jonze the King of All Wild Things!
I'm fairly certain none of the millions of fans of the Twilight movies could give a rat's ass what a jaded film critic thinks about it. And so, I'm not going to be one.
Here's the REAL ugly truth: The Ugly Truth is an uninspiring romantic-comedy rehash.
Admire a franchise that has matured, along with its main players. The well-played Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince is an excellent next step towards the boy wizard saga's inevitable end.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Finally admit to yourself Zac Efron may just have the stuff to make it big. Do it. Do it NOW.
First and foremost, State of Play is a love letter to the now dying print/newspaper industry. Remember that and you'll get the gist of the film.
Could the Wolverine story be getting a little tired at this point, even though Hugh Jackman still looks good with mutton chops? Possibly ...
Pure escapist fun.
This is about a marriage and family and all the ups and downs that entails -- and how a beloved pet can be an integral part.
J. Lo's mass appeal will bring them in, but the mediocrity of the film won't give them much more.
Quote not available.
movie_title: The Curse of the Jade Scorpion (2001)

movie_review_blurb: If you need an actor to look good in an underground street fight, hire Channing Tatum.
Overall, Arctic Tale's one true message is clear: Stop global warming before it's too late.
Just when you think he should be retiring, Clint Eastwood throws another one-two punch.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
The film steps up a notch when the action is on the field. However, many directors before him have portrayed the beloved sport better.
Quote not available.
A dastardly unadulterated delight of a film.
movie_title: Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Director Paul W.S. Anderson really isn't known for Oscar contenders, but the guy understands over-the-top gratuitous violence better than most.
Smell that sweet, sweet Summer air. This is a simply heartfelt, totally engaging and refreshingly realistic romantic comedy.
Boldly go and revel in the awesomeness and nostalgia this action-packed prequel will elicit.
The Brothers Bloom is an intriguingly offbeat yarn that unfortunately unravels towards the end.
Get ready for more shock waves. With Bruno, Sacha Baron Cohen again pushes the sociopolitical comedy envelope as far as he can.
The woefully unfunny I Love You, Beth Cooper is a teen sex comedy's worst enemy.
Expect good but not great. Despite the clear talent behind this highly competent film, it is a little disappointing Public Enemies is not as Best Picture quality as it purports to be.
Thaw out in Jurassic Park with the fun-lovin' Ice Age gang %u2013 and throw all logic out the window.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Bring lots of tissue. If you don't tear up watching My Sister's Keeper, at least just a little, then your heart is made of stone.
Prepare for bigger metal crunchers, louder explosion and more of Megan Fox's glossy lips.
Pointless and droll? Definitely, but 'Year One' still has its moments.
Pay attention and you might learn something.
Know this: There are no original romantic comedies anymore, only original people in them. Sandra Bullock and Ryan Reynolds make The Proposal a lot better than it ought to be.
Hire Denzel Washington. He is bound to make any mediocre film better than it should, which is precisely what he does in The Taking of Pelham 1 2 3.
Embrace the inane wackiness that is Land of the Lost. Seriously, you need to chuck any rational thought and just let yourself enjoy this one %u2013 and don't feel ashamed about it.
While I'm not saying you have to be hungover to appreciate The Hangover, having a wild night out before seeing this the next day might enhance this hilarious experience.
Watch Sam Raimi get his horror groove back.
Hold onto your seats as Pixar takes you on yet another delightful adventure Up, up and away.
Maybe not as fresh and unique as the first one, the sequel has enough laugh-out-loud moments to enjoy.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Terminator Salvation proves the machines-against-man-raging-against-the-machines franchise is still alive and kicking. Kicking A**, that is.
Imagine That this innocuous family comedy could very well bring a smile to a little girl's face, especially if she sees it with her daddy.
Quote not available.
Might be best just to let these sleeping Old Dogs lie. This incredibly loony comedy sort of demeans everyone involved.
Carved almost verbatim from Cormac McCarthy's compelling novel, The Road is a depressing, gut-wrenching journey that is strangely uplifting at its core.
This incredible cinematic masterpiece takes you on a high-octane acid trip that gloriously assaults your senses... probably one the best action movies you'll ever see.
Fully embrace this Avengers sequel in all its Marvel-ousness! Despite some minor flaws, Age of Ultron packs an expected and welcomed thrill-ride punch.
Age of Adaline surprises you with its warmth and sweeping romantic notions, despite its severely flawed logic.
Listen to the film's message: Don't cyberbully or you could unleash the ghost in the machine.
Rev your engines... and grab the tissues. Furious 7 delivers the same outrageous thrill ride you expect , but tears will also flow for the late Paul Walker.
Mr. Popper's Penguins will certainly delight the kiddies, but their parents might wish for a tad more Jim Carrey irreverence.
No need to tread lightly. The third installment to the Chronicles of Narnia definitely fairs better than the last one, Prince Caspian, but it still can't hold a candle to the first Narnia movie
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The whole film is much like a meditation session, reflecting on relationships and personal growth... a nice change of pace from the summer movies.
Remember the game of reading fortune cookie proclamations out loud and ending them with the phrase 'in bed'? That's sort of how I feel Love and Other Drugs ended many scenes--in bed.
Fair Game may make your jaw hurt from clenching your teeth...
Let Me In is simply riveting, dark and ominous, cruel and unrelenting, sprinkled with bittersweet moments and sentiment.
Easy A gets an A+ for keeping the teen high school comedy clever and quirky.
Relatively low on the cheese meter and high on realistic visual effects, Poseidon is just plain good old fashioned disaster flick fun, perfect for a summer evening at the movies.
While Eat Pray Love has some enlightening, touching, visually breathtaking moments, you still end up praying it would end.
The Other Guys takes this summer's crown for best and most quotable comedy.
The ending will leave you debating in that glass half-full, half-empty kind of way. Let's just say, it's a movie that needs to be seen more than once.
The only thing distinguishing Conviction from a Lifetime TV movie is the star power.
Despicable Me follows a tried and true formula of good story decent animation = entertaining family film. But it isn't quite up to Pixar quality.
This excellent mockumentary highlights the business of teaching high-school kids to hilarious and poignant effect.
Applaud the hotter-than-hot Amy Schumer... Trainwreck just works, from start to finish.
If you're expecting the same kind of chilling horror the first Strangers delivered, you might be disappointed with The Strangers: Prey at Night.
Annihilation will be an acquired taste and should start some conversations.
Game Night still delivers a requisite amount of worthy laughs.
Please Stand By gives Dakota Fanning a much-deserved time to shine like we know she can.

As far as weepy summer romantic dramas go, Me Before You may be a tad more predictable and not quite a three-hankie tearjerker, but it still achieves the requisite feels, buoyed by an effervescent performance from Emilia Clarke.
While it isn't as stellar as the first two - First Class and Days of Future Past - X-Men: Apocalypse still manages to thrill you with its mutant action and impeccable characterizations.
The Nice Guys is just pure wackiness all the way through - a straight-up crime mystery filled with hilarious antics and plenty of violence. A perfect addition to the summer movie roster.
Jurassic World just proves people still love them some dinos and what's not to love? The dinosaurs are better than ever...

Buckle in. The ultimate battle of superhero titans is about to take off in Marvel's Captain America: Civil War and hold onto your seats, folks, because this is one helluva ride - and the best Marvel movie to date.
Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice isn't in any way a perfect comic book movie, but it has enough going for it that will make fans happy.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Altered Minds moves almost too slowly through a family's dynamics but culminates with a heart-wrenching punch in the gut.
Midnight Special shrouds its sci-fi story in marvelous mystery but tackles the narrative's complexities with heart and soul. Another winner from writer/director Jeff Nichols.
Make sure to bring someone with you who doesn't mind if you unexpectedly grab their arm. 10 Cloverfield Lane is one of the best psychological thrillers to come along in awhile.
A big-screen adaptation of the best-selling novel took some time to reach theaters, but it was worth the wait. PPZ is rip-roaring, zombie guts-spewin', Jane Austen conventional fun.
Star Wars: The Force Awakens is just what the fans have been hoping and dreaming about for a long, long time.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The intent to show something meaningful, something personal in "By the Sea" is lost in the slow, morose drag of it all.
For a third installment in a series, Barbershop: The Next Cut feels just as original and relevant as if this were the first one.
After all the other animated CGI films this year, Planet 51 just feels like a rehash, and not nearly as charming as it wants to be.
For the Twihard fans, Eclipse should thrill and excite to no end; for the rest of the world, it stands as the best of the three in the saga.
The Duplass Brothers demand your undivided attention. Thanks to their sincere way with words and experience with examining distressed relationships, you will gladly give it to them.
On the surface, Edge of Darkness might seem like your typical violent revenge thriller, but it actually has some intriguing layers and surprising twists that get your full attention.
End of the world much? As yet ANOTHER twist on the apocalypse, Legion could have done with a lot less pontificating and much more action to mask the muddled plot.
Disney likes their formulas, and they've found one with Dwayne Johnson and family flicks. Boring, but true.
This adrenaline-fueled cross between The Road Warrior and The Ten Commandments gets a tad heavy-handed at times.
Give it an A for effort, C for execution. As cool/creepy as it seems, Daybreakers just doesn't quite measure up to its potential.
Michael Cera puts another notch in his droll performance belt.
It's Complicated thankfully isn't %u2013 as a romantic comedy, that is. It's pretty straight forward, funny stuff, bolstered by terrific performances and a script that zings.
Chalk up The White Ribbon as one of those German art films, in which the images are stark and minimalistic, the action languid and slow, and little to nothing is either revealed nor resolved.
As movie musicals go, Nine doesn't necessarily have that wow factor, but it certainly has enough terrific performances to make it entertaining.
While it showcases Jeff Bridges' extraordinary talents and delivers a couple of decent country music tunes, Crazy Heart is basically a retread that doesn't leave much of a lasting impression.
Pay attention to what James Cameron has done with his truly spectacular looking Avatar. This, my friends, is the right way to create a 3D film experience.
The film is a wonderful reminder of how Disney truly is the king of hand-drawn animation, with the rich, lush backgrounds and a fluidity in the characters that you really can't get anywhere else.

First-time director Tom Ford paints his own portrait of A Single Man almost as if it were a piece of art, beautiful to look at, solitary and still, but with many layers of emotions hidden underneath. It's a pure gem.
Peter Jackson's The Lovely Bones is a beautiful, thoughtful film, full of dark mystery and life affirmations, yet somehow it's lacking a certain inner strength.
On the one hand, Invictus is a serviceable sports flick, but on the other, it's a heartfelt true story of one great leader's unyielding quest to unite his country.
This is one of those all-encompassing dramedies that makes you laugh, cry, contemplate life, hope for better times, believe in family %u2013 but it doesn't stick with you after it's over.

Fueled by director Guy Ritchie's fast-paced action and Robert Downey Jr.'s uncanny skill at inventing his own unique spin on his characters, Sherlock Holmes thoroughly entertains from beginning to end.
The film does a nice job re-envisioning the '80s cult classic, thanks in large part to the new Kid, Jaden Smith.
Dear John can't elevate itself from the same, repetitive Sparks cycle.
Sure, Valentine's Day smacks cute and is probably an adequate date movie, but it doesn't really inspire genuine tingling, feel-good sentiments that a well-crafted film of this genre should do.
It doesn't try to surpass its predecessors but simply continues the story in such a wonderful, natural progression that it melds with ease into the brilliance that is the Toy Story lore.
Get yourself to see the Greek. It's raunchy, tasteless, hilarious, and surprisingly poignant (at times).
Prince of Persia is the sort of popcorn-eating, mindless actioner you'd expect for the summer, made only slightly more appealing by Jake Gyllenhaal's performance.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: You're in good shape if you don't demand much from your comedies.
It'd be difficult for any additional Iron Man incarnation to surpass the original, but Iron Man 2 is a worthy follow-up.
Nice try, but they probably should have just left the original Nightmare on Elm Street as is.
After watching this stylized comic-book action flick and admitting you thoroughly enjoyed yourself, you won't feel like a Loser at all.

While this Wolfman redo certainly doesn't live up to its 1941 predecessor, it serves its purpose. That is, if you like a somewhat dull, Gothic story that only gets exciting once the guy grows hair and big teeth.
Kick-Ass lives up to its name ...
Training dragons never looked more fun.
The Runaways does nothing to distinguish itself from previous depictions of the lives and excesses of our most beloved and most tragic rock and pop icons.
Repo Men is a thrilling, bloody, organ-ripping sci-fi spin on a familiar theme.
Think of this as the fourth Bourne adventure.
The off-kiltered Tim Burton version of Alice in Wonderland might frightened younger children, confuse older ones and bore the adults.
Is it a Cop Out to make a throwback to the '80s buddy cop comedy instead of doing something original? Maybe, but at least it'll make you laugh out loud a few times.
Like it or not, director Martin Scorsese uses his Shutter Island to mess with your brain, on all levels, and mostly succeeds in his endeavor.
Definitely go on this Date.
Ah, another lifeless comedy for the holidays. It's just super to be reminded how mean-spirited and grotesquely commercial the Christmas season can be, isn't it?
Ben Affleck crafts a compelling, tight-knit bank heist drama.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Shedding the confines of the original 1990s live-action versions, the new TMNT runs free with crisp, malleable animation and kick-ass action.
I Think I Love My Wife is mainly just another Chris Rock routine, tied up in a fancier, more adult bow.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Here's a Premonition for you: This ill-conceived thriller isn't going to do anything for Sandra Bullock's career.
While bolstered by an intriguing premise, the thriller The Number 23 cops out for a slick, Hollywood-ized ending
Billy Bob Thornton finally sheds his Bad Santa-ness to play an everyday hero in the uplifting, if slightly cornball, family drama.
Imaginative, touching and keenly attuned to the coming-of-age genre, Bridge to Terabithia is a welcomed breath of fresh air in the stale family movie arena.
What Music and Lyrics may lack in romantic zing, it makes up for by featuring Hugh Grant in tight pants and a bad '80s hairdo
Whatever your expectations may be...Is it about benevolent aliens from the future? Supernatural phenomena?...it may ultimately disappoint you with its cluttered derivativeness.
Eddie Murphy in another fat suit? What could possibly go wrong with that? Oh, plenty, let me tell you.
Despite its predictability, all that stompin' in this Yard will get you moving in your seat.
From the producers of the Shrek series comes this annoying Shrek ripoff, a wannabe fairytale spoof with no imagination.
At times, Freedom Writers invokes genuine emotions, but this derivative teacher-inspires-troubled-kids movie mostly just pries your eyes open and jerks the tears out.
Miss Potter vividly paints the picture of an inspirational woman who created lovely childhood memories of bedtime stories...
A wonderfully salacious and psychologically controlling character piece, which brilliantly showcases two of the industry's more gifted actresses.
A genuine thrill ride with a soul.
Ben Stiller and gang still manage to give the delightfully entertaining Night at the Museum a little edge.
Catch and Release is another middle-of-the-road romantic dramedy, neither offensively bad nor terribly inspiring either, despite its best efforts.
Its the talking pig movie for the next generation!
Although sometimes too frenetic for its own good, Meet the Robinsons still manages to awe and inspire with its earnest messages and digital 3-D brilliance.
While not for the faint of heart, Aqua Teen Hunger Force is perfectly suited for the seriously twisted followers--and new recruits--of the Cartoon Network show.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: You know you're in trouble when the outtakes during the end credits are the best part.
Ratatouille is a Pixar tour de force.
You can stop cringing at the idea of another Die Hard installment. Bruce Willis nails it in this fourth go-around...
Forget wrath-of-God stuff. Evan Almighty is pure fluff, moderately entertaining but not nearly the "comedy of Biblical proportions" it purports to be.
Stripped of unnecessary gore and predictable scare tactics, 1408 is a chilling psychological mind-bender, which stays true to its Stephen King roots.
Placing the old-style teen super sleuth in a contemporary setting is a risky move, but buoyed by an appealing lead performance, this Nancy Drew update mostly keeps to the spirit of the beloved books.
Third time's a charm. Ocean's Thirteen outshines the second installment, offering that certain breezy fun the original provided. Those cutie pies just work better in Vegas.
Yes, Will Ferrell is once again playing a macho jerk in dire need to learn some life lessons--in spandex and ice skates, no less. But honestly, can anyone else do it better?
Surf's Up shoots you right through the tube.

Is this third installment an overblown, drawn-out spectacle with more plot twists than a pretzel factory? Perhaps. Does it still deliver a visually stunning, wham-bam conclusion to a rousing pirate trilogy? Absolutely.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Shrek the Third pretty much serves up the same tired fairytale shenanigans with little of the original's magic. Still, the franchise's undeniable charm alleviates some of the Third 's banality.
Strong performances and its R rating help keep Georgia Rule from being a completely overemotional, Lifetime TV mush fest, but only slightly.
If you really listen to Mike White's quirky but ultimately realistic view on life as its dealt out, you'll really enjoy this stellar effort from the burgeoning filmmaking talent.
Tired of really bad action movies starring Nicolas Cage? Sigh. So are we.
Pairing veteran Anthony Hopkins with upstart Ryan Gosling in a smartly written cat-and-mouse game is a brilliant idea.
What those hilarious Shaun of the Dead guys did for zombie flicks, they do for buddy-cop movies in Hot Fuzz. Be careful not to call it a spoof, though.
Score one for Kevin Costner. His dark and disturbingly compelling psychological thriller Mr. Brooks could give the once powerful Dances with Wolves star his first hit in many moons.
Less flash, more grit, The Order of the Phoenix is definitely the most introspective of the Harry Potter movies.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Watching The Holiday is a little like ordering a sticky cinnamon bun: You know the gooey, warm sweetness will taste good, but you'll feel guilty eating it.
...eclectic director Darren Aronofsky makes The Fountain work. In a really weird way.
The Night Listener is a rather intense psychological character piece that keeps you on edge, as well as intrigued, with the promise of malevolence at every turn.
Barnyard is a one-note premise that falls flat after about 10 minutes.
In the typical vein of high school teen movies full of joie de vivre, John Tucker Must Die is unadulterated fluff. Derivative but somewhat amusing.

Gone are the pastels, the pet alligator from this dark, gritty modern-day version of the '80s TV show. Unfortunately, gone too is some of that fresh style that made the show unique, leaving us with just another dark, gritty crime drama.

The fantastical Lady in the Water, Shyamalan's most wildly imaginative yet obscure work to date, will probably disappoint those looking for that certain Shyamalan je n'sais quoi. Still, you can't fault the guy for being an original
Captain Jack is back and in rare form in this swashbuckling, booty-licious Pirates sequel which more than equals its predecessor.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: If The Devil Wears Prada didn't have the silently menacing Meryl Streep as its title character, the film would be sporting nubs and carrying a broom instead of full-blown horns and a pitch fork.
SoaP is everything its cracked up to be and more, a monster movie and disaster flick rolled into one
Waist Deep is just another one of those middle-of-the-road action flicks.
Sure, the story is pretty predictable and farfetched but that's not why you're seeing this. It's all about the drift, baby!
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: There's really only two words to describe remaking cult classic The Omen: Not necessary.
The Break-Up is indeed the refreshingly anti-romantic comedy that it purports to be. But somehow in eliminating most of the clichés, some of the comic energy is zapped as well.
Its action-packed but lacks that certain mutant angst.
Leave it to a bunch of hilarious woodland critters to teach us suburbia-bound humans a few things about living life Over the Hedge.
Ron Howard's beautifully framed The Da Vinci Code sticks to author Dan Brown's controversial wild goose-chase thriller pretty religiously.
Quote not available.
It's really unnerving to have to sit through a second Garfield when the first was just so excruciating. But alas, here we are again--and now there's two of them. Joy.
movie_title: Garfield: A Tail of Two Kitties (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Blood Diamond maintains a certain level of intensity that will certainly stir the soul and perhaps inspire activism. But unfortunately, it also tries a little too hard to convey its message about global conflict.
Could possibly gain Frat Pack pledge Justin Long his own acceptance.
Invincible does nothing to improve on the already very tired sports underdog theme.
Daniel Craig is all THAT and a bag of chips. Kudos to the new Bond regime.
Is it good for those Gladiator dudes Ridley Scott and Russell Crowe to team up again for a romantic comedy about winemaking in the South of France? Perhaps not, but it's a nice try.
Well-placed pop-culture references, wry British humor%u2014and some singing slugs%u2014elevate Flushed Away from the typical animated fare, but only slightly.
OK, so Santa Clause 3 isn't the stuff classic Christmas movies are made of, but the franchise still manages to invoke some genuine Yuletide spirit. Hard to believe, but it's true.
movie_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Infamous is a thoughtful, emotional and oftentimes hysterical re-telling of Truman Capote's life-altering experience in Kansas. It might actually be better than that other Capote movie.
Flicka is a classic tearjerker but may be a little too old-fashioned for its own good.
The secret agent actioner Stormbreaker is definitely more James Bond for tweens than Nickelodeon fluff like Agent Cody Banks. Maybe it has something to do with the British accents.
Elusive and stunningly rich, The Illusionist, with its big-budget look and indie sensibilities, is a haunting romance wrapped in an enigma.
I mean, for all I know, I could be cursed for just watching this nonsense. Wait, what's that under my desk?
If you're going to retire from the biz, might as well do it with some style.
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Basically, this remake of All the King's Men is a nice way to take a two-hour nap, despite Sean Penn's fervent attempts to wake you up.

The moral of this story is if you steal a kung-fu master's elephants, you WILL have your legs broken. Period.
Trust me, a Woody Allen film it is not.

The question isn't whether Jason Statham knows how to Crank things up. The question is whether or not you're willing to go with him on yet another highly implausible, blood-soaked, adrenaline-pumped ride.
As yet another children's novel-turned-big-screen flick, Fried Worms has all the wholesome goodness of tomato soup, while the side of crispy larva gives it an extra kick.
After months of dreary, brain-addled kiddie flicks, finally one that makes you laugh.
Hairspray is a Grease for the new millennium, just the kind of bubblegum musical that keeps your toes tappin', except this time John Travolta is wearing a fat suit and nylons. Shiver.
...a more poignant and subtle point of view than what director Christopher Guest and his improvisational entourage have served up in their past efforts.
No delicacies here. No Reservations is just as bland and predictable as a frozen TV dinner.
For a premise that sounds a bit shaky, the cast of Role Models simply sell it.

You can feel the kids in the audience tapping their feet, waiting for more action. So, let's just give the kids what they want: fast-paced excitement, wrapped up in a colorful package.
A modern-day romance between two mature people.
Slightly better than most.

What it really boils down to is whether you're a fan of Larry the Cable Guy. If so, you'll (I would hope) realize you're watching a pretty stupid comedy but will laugh in the appropriate parts.

Quote not available.
As far as romantic comedies go, the hackneyed Over Her Dead Body falls more towards the bottom of the heap
A derivative yawner.
While being a serviceable, somewhat female-empowering bank-heist comedy, Mad Money doesn't do much else to distinguish itself.
God save Cate Blanchett. Without her performance, this second history lesson on Elizabeth I's reign would be a little dry.
OK, just so long as you don't expect the old Farrelly magic.
He [Joe Nussbaum] pretty much directs by the numbers.
The Jane Austen Book Club is definitely chick lit-turned-chick flick, but an engaging script and winning performances elevate it from its cheesy TV movie-of-the-week potential.
This Disney fluff isn't going to score any touchdowns, but by following a lighthearted Game Plan, it should stack up points with the family set.

Filled with wonderfully conflicted characters, Michael Clayton is a masterful legal thriller that never misses a beat. A true diamond in the rough.

John Lennon would be proud.

movie_review_blurb: P.S. I Love You isn't as pathetically sappy as the title might sound. OK, maybe it is a little...
Out of the rash of socio-political movies this season, this stands as the best; thanks in large part to the film's trio of stars and the snarky script from Aaron Sorkin.

27 Dresses sort of grows on you, thanks to Katherine Heigl's performance.
I Am Legend is Will Smith's one-man sci-fi thrill show, entertaining in all the ways we've come to expect from the talented actor.
This Lord of the Rings wannabe gives fantasy adventures a bad name.
movie_title: In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It grabs your heart and doesn't let go.
Disney's Enchanted is the sweet, lighthearted antithesis to the more serious fare this holiday season, fueled by a thoroughly captivating performance from Amy Adams.
With his chilling, ultimately bleak adaptation of The Mist, writer/director Frank Darabont once again successfully channels Stephen Kingâ(TM)s twisted psyche on the big screen.
For all its hi-tech wonder, motion-capture technology still hasn't perfected the human factor.
Proving why he's still an American classic, 83-year-old director Sidney Lumet turns in another brilliantly executed crime thriller
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Fred Claus is pure Vince Vaughn hijinks, but the PG, family-friendly mode may not be his most advantageous venue.

Although this might be a tad convoluted and distant for the younger set, The Golden Compass is still a truly fantastical journey filled with wondrous imagery.

Slow West is a stunning two hander that charms its way across the prairies of Colorado with a pack of gun-toting desperados in tow.
Marjane Satrapi's surreal sense of humour makes The Voices a gory and unexpectedly pleasurable dark comedy.
Johnson has created a successfully gritty Brit flick in the mould of Sexy Beast with the over-saturated neon visuals of TV's Red Riding and Drive.

It's important to probe the Western world's overconsumption of sugar, but Gameau's attempts to do so while being hip and fun feel condescending and trite.
Marquardt leaves too much intentional ambiguity for her film to fall victim to predictability.

A feeling of foreboding sets in early in Kiah Roache-Turner's zombie-apocalypse thriller Wyrmwood: Road Of The Dead. Unfortunately, it has nothing to do with the hellish subject matter and everything to do with the direction.
Love, Rosie's early charm fades by the end, given that, as time (and the movie) wears on, neither Rosie nor Alex get any more mature when it comes to matters of the heart.
Combing horror, film noir and westerns, Ana Lily Amirpour's debut feature, A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night, is a refreshing take on vampire lore.
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Love hurts, but Jeremy Garelick's The Wedding Ringer is truly painful.

In his approach to bringing his own story to the screen, the author gave no consideration for actual performance or humor, valuing his language over all else.
At times, Animal strikes a compelling, raw quality, but this is largely lost due to the overwritten script and sprawling, though lovingly rendered, cast of characters.
The film is 112 minutes, but feels as long and as arduous as Davidson's real-life trek.
Never amounts to anything more than its title's shallow descriptors.
The parable resonates emotionally thanks to Trzebuchowska's performance.
Overall during his stand up, the directors never manage to capture Hart's... well, heart.
Hammer might be back, but the studio sure isn't hammering out anything that's remotely horrifying.
The destination doesn't feel worth the journey.
Eden forces a few things, but it's punctuated with enough moments of genuine exuberance and humour to offset its flaws.
It's a parlour trick, creating the illusion of activism while passively watching. Dark arts, indeed.
Wiseman does what he does best: creates a holistic sense of a place as an organic habitat rather than a mere organization.
[Trick or Treaty] deceptively simple and entirely powerful-no gimmicks, no gags, no tricks.
...the film doesn't wallow in her dire circumstances and instead celebrates the agency and beauty that exists all around her.
But even with this sagging middle, From Deep's rejection of conventional doc form comes as a welcome reprieve from the norm in this mode of filmmaking.
As a project exploring collective documentation, From Gulf to Gulf is fascinating.
movie_title: From Gulf To Gulf To Gulf (2013)

movie_review_blurb: '71 takes an ethno-nationalist conflict rooted in hundreds of years of colonialist history and makes it beige, apolitical and gutless.
Estonian director Marti Helde eschews the form of the standard historical biopic for an exploration of time, which literally stands still onscreen via a series of tableaux vivants.

... Narimane Mari's Bloody Beans is riveting from start to finish.
Moving into darker territory where the mumblecore milieu would never venture, Short Term 12 offers a much-needed corrective to the indie-darling set-particularly in its curiously optimistic ending.
Through their awe-inspiring images of rivers and tides, Burtynsky and Baichwal carve out a space for reflection about where and how we mere mortals fit within this watery world.

There's no beauty or inspiration in the film's shooting style, and most importantly, no terror. If this is "ingenious" horror filmmaking, as the programme note suggests, get me off this planet.

The film refuses the old adage that all you need is love, rooting both their stories in harsher socio-economic realities. The film is slight, but there's enough there to pique interest in what Barta does next.
With Robert Lepage and Pedro Pires' Triptych, you get three terrible films for the price of one.
The film creates both a fresh text from old conventions and fresh kills with innocuous objects.
Admirable aims, to be sure, but overall the film is as awkward as a cow on a crutch.
A sci-fi movie with grand, out-of-this-world ambitions that ultimately doesn't quite live up to them.

Audition emerges as the most harrowing, unforgiving slice of shock cinema since Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer.
Succumb to its creepy charms, and you'll never see inner-ear anatomy diagrams, umbrellas, or escargot in quite the same way. You might even hand over laundry chores to someone else.

Smacks viewers alongside the head like a desperate junkie hunting down his fix money.

By focusing on fewer ideas, and resisting the urge to bit off more than he can chew, perhaps Kaufman can shape his next vision into a more focused work. In the meantime, let's rejoice that he's here.

A journey spanning nearly three decades of bittersweet camaraderie and history, in which we feel that we truly know what makes Holly and Marina tick, and our hearts go out to them as both continue to negotiate their imperfect, love-hate relationship.
As a self-assured exercise in style and plotting, I suppose that Confidence works. Yet, there's something emotionally unsatisfying about its characters.
[A] cardboard, fast-food vat of lowest common-denominator fluff.
A vertical, high-flying rush of a movie.

movie_review_blurb: One of the year's best films.
Forget Freddy Versus Jason. For a real horror show, try The Magdalene Sisters.
Linklater and his actors understand passion. They understand enthusiasm.
It's one movie that definitely goes to eleven.

Moody, heartbreaking, and filmed in a natural, unforced style that makes its characters seem entirely convincing even when its script is not.

The next best thing to a backstage pass.

Second-string Woo.

movie_review_blurb: After a rather unsavory start, Frailty develops into anything but that which its title suggests, opting instead to become a strong, good old-fashioned suspense/horror story with lots of creepiness along the way.
