Winchester is let down by the mythos that surrounds the creation of the mansion itself, saddled with living up to a haunting history that might have only existed in Sarah Winchester's head.
The Greys become the old married couple who are so boring that even their sex doesn't look particularly new anymore.
Larson is cute but this is far beneath her talents.
Black Panther isn't just a great movie for the first half of the year; Black Panther is the best movie Marvel's ever made!
Annihilation is a thing of immense beauty and intoxicating complexity.
Unpleasant and unnecessarily exploitative of its female lead, the film exists only to show off its leading lady's body, breaking her down as a means of "empowering" her.
Film Stars is a basic biopic that, in spite of its fantastic leads, doesn't leave an impression.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A raucous ode to the shutterbug raconteur embraces the glamour of his lifestyle, while keeping the man himself at arm's length.
Cars 3 is a decent reconstituted Rocky with a bizarre faux feminist subplot and beautiful animation.
One of the Mouse House's most sumptuous looking films from an animation standpoint.
A muddled descent into psycho-sexual mind games that never fully gels.
Dunkirk shows off Nolan's own techniques as a filmmaker to make for a film that is technically, if not completely narratively, lustrous.
Slow and baffling at times, A Ghost Story follows you, not unlike the undead spirit within its frame.
It sticks with you to haunt and influence your nightmares!
Stronger isn't the year's best movie, but it tries something new.
In spite of a fantastic cast, Suburbicon never truly invites you in.
Sacred Deer is definitely unique but its substance is often too insurmountable to be accessible.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Murder on the Orient Express is nothing more than serviceable.
Queen Mimi is a comforting balm for the soul.
If you're already fascinated by the world of religious fanaticism, Holy Hell will leave you captivated.
Director David Rühm's German language vamp-com Therapy for a Vampire gives the vampire film a much needed transfusion.
movie_title: Therapy for a Vampire (Der Vampir auf der Couch) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Beautifully filmed with serious kinetic energy by director Taika Waititi, with a crackling script, Thor: Ragnarok is a heap of fun. Cue "Immigrant Song!"
It's remarkable how Gibney packs complex, jargon-heavy ideas into a neat package.
Had Nerve stuck to the intrigue around online games, it could have been an efficiently entertaining piece of cinema.
Pete's Dragon is family entertainment at its best.
Ben-Hur isn't the worst film of the year, but from a technical standpoint it certainly looks it.
Hands of Stone isn't the black eye on the boxing genre, but it presents the genre at its most mediocre and formulaic.
Yoga Hosers is not the complete abortion of a film it's reputed to be, but Smith gets in his own way far too often.
The film touches on the line between poetic license and deceit, as well as the glittering promise of reinvention and fame.
Howard assembles Eight Days a Week with an eye to appeasing those knowledgeable about Beatles history.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: If you're a fan of British music-themed dramas, London Town is right up your alley.
King Cobra takes an interesting true crime and covers it in exploitative sex, pedophilic overtures and acting that would make a high school drama teacher cringe.
A necessity for anyone interested in analyzing Lumet's work or those just interested in watching good films.
Maybe Illumination and Universal should look at why Pixar succeeds instead of just ripping them off and regurgitating the leftovers.

Although set half a century prior to today, Loving is a timely reminder, especially in a political season filled with so much hatred and divisiveness, of the overwhelming power of quiet and selfless love.
A tearjerker that's not without its charms.
Marvel's heartfelt and wonderfully down to Earth approach to Spider-Man is a winner.
An eye-opening look at marriage culture in India.
Although Lucy is on a journey of self-discovery, she often hurts others in her quest for herself. That makes Hirayanagi's take on the later-in-life coming-of-age story more honest than most.
The few bursts of excitement and humor found along the way just aren't enough to make "The Road Movie" worth the trip.
It's refreshing to see a film about the refugee crisis that doesn't rely on cliche, but the fact remains: The mundane is mundane.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In the end, the overarching theme of "Tom of Finland" is the power of art, even - or maybe especially - so-called deviant art.
"Brimstone & Glory's" greatest grace comes from its subjects, whom Jakovleski neither patronizes nor fetishizes.

Although the action of the film is chronological, Bron hops around from place to place - boardroom, dressing room, practice room - and from subject to subject, so quickly that, without guidance, it's nearly impossible to place anything in context.
The film's last shot is a gasp-inducing long look at Hamilton triumphantly skimming across a wave for what seems like minutes. In the end, that ride isn't worth the work it takes to get there.
movie_title: Take Every Wave: The Life of Laird Hamilton (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Le Week-End is not a bleak film, but it delves so frequently into uncomfortable truths and very personal injuries.

The derivative nature of Dom Hemingway's mouthy, swaggering gangster archetype combines with the aimlessness of the script to create a character piece that goes nowhere, except everywhere we've already been.
The reveal is eye-rollingly bad, a moment of affected profundity Michod's long, winding road trip never earns.
Blancanieves is a truly stunning motion picture, the kind of movie that makes you glad the movies exist.
Runoff's finely-observed, understated performances invoke a kind of heartland neo-realism.
Borgman is a film that lingers long after it's ended.

You know what they say: go big or go home, and Kong should've gone all out with the thrills in order to, at the very least, make up for the alarming lack of character development or something resembling a decent script.
American Ultra, built upon ridiculous premise and casting, is not only the funniest but unexpectedly one of the best action movies of the summer.
The downfall of The Final Girls is that it pretty much becomes the tired thing it makes fun of. And it doesn't do much for thrills.

What [Guillermo] del Toro had in mind when shooting Crimson Peak was probably a stylish gothic period piece in the same acclaimed lane as Pan's Labyrinth. Unfortunately, Crimson Peak fails to work on that level.
From sly, not-so-sly innuendo to unfiltered climaxes, there's not a moment in this movie that isn't packed with jokes. And the thing is, it works.
Go see it, it's fun and spooky, I recommend it.
Even when you're squirming in your seat from the sheer length of the film, you'll definitely find yourself jumping out of it a lot too.
If you're squirmish...it may be best to stay away-but we dare you not to.
This is [Noah] Baumbach on a new level, thanks to [Greta] Gerwig-bless this woman-who keeps her comedic charm throughout even the strangest territories.
Room takes a nightmarish premise in an impossibly contained set and turns it into one of this year's most emotionally poignant films.
To call Carol a Christmas miracle feels like a gaudy understatement, but that's sort of exactly what it is.
Through its ups and downs, Listen to Me, at its core, is a gift for the fans. It's like an audiobook for the cinephiles and Brando lovers-almost like a bedtime story from Brando himself.

Truth is all about Blanchett, who really shines in-and carries-an otherwise bad good movie. (Or is it a good bad movie?) There are a lot of themes introduced, but are stated in rather sweeping gestures.

The latest film from acclaimed Selma director Ava DuVernay is a much-needed, sobering punch to the face that eloquently contextualizes the current state of America and one of its most important issues.
Like its title, with those synonymous adjectives, Simon Aboud's film strings together a story that strains to be charming while actually being immediately predictable.
Like It Follows (and, really, all good horror movies), Raw is more than just body horror. It is as much about the horror of the feminine body itself, as well as the horror of growing up.
Blair Witch is probably fascinating for young viewers who had never seen the original movie and didn't live through that hype, but for those familiar, it offers nothing new.
Despite being marketed under the mainstream bait of a "space movie," The Martian is, more than anything, a love letter to science, without ever feeling like a boring textbook.
Sure, there's voiceover, freeze frames, and morally reprehensible characters, but it reads more like a parody film than an inspired one.
Felt is a fascinating movie-one that belongs on this year's list of "you've never seen anything like it!"
I honestly can't remember the last time I had this much fun at the movies, so I'm just gonna come out and say it: This is my favorite movie of the year.
This movie would have been better with a heavier focus on just these two rather than bringing in their SNL entourage
In a film where nothing much happens, and even less is comprehensible, the Quays have managed to make short films more terrifying than most feature-length horrors.
A hilarious, heartfelt picture that feels refreshingly original despite having an age-old synopsis.
Subtext is everything here, especially when so much is at stake. Doremus forces us to think about what it means to live, love, and be human.
All This Panic will make you feel all the feels-excitement, confusion, sadness, anger, pining, and certainly all this panic-and heighten them to teen levels.
Things come to a halt before the going gets really good.
There's even a sense that not enough happens but the repression-a lot of glancing, no touching-feels right with the tone, and especially within the cultural context, of the film.
For a drama about death, it's also incredibly funny-not just wry funny, but also body humor funny-making for an interesting mix. Moretti is able to pull it off masterfully, and with heart.

Done right, this story about three Bronx high school students whose futures are in jeopardy because of their undocumented immigration status could have been powerful and necessary. The film itself, unfortunately, falls short.

Jordan Peele has made something scathing, hilarious, and -- as unlikely as this may sound -- totally fresh. I am pleased -- who am I kidding? I'm f----g thrilled -- to announce that Get Out is a legitimately great movie.

The Monster lacks bite in the actual horror department, but like many other good horror films before it (Rosemary's Baby, The Shining), it plays with the anxiety of this very primal fear-the betrayal of the mother.
Depp sticks out like a sore thumb in an otherwise bland crime drama. And when the film isn't distracting, it's mostly just plain boring.
With The Tribe, the power of communication is restructured and re-examined, with a story that's strange and disturbing enough to haunt you.
Despite its repulsiveness, The Greasy Strangler has a dreamlike quality about it: It's so un-life-like, that you're transported to a fantasy world that's unmistakably a cinematic creation.
At its core, this is a hilarious movie; it just happens to star two transgender women as the lead. That alone is worthy of note.

There's a lot to love in Personal Shopper, including Assayas's loving lens on Stewart as she tries on expensive clothing, and that certain je ne sais quoi of a French art film that is nothing like any other ghost film you've ever seen before.
I felt like I had lived it, and not just because of its nearly three-hour runtime.
The Dark Below could've easily been half the length - and half the waste of time - if Schulze hadn't used slo-mo in nearly every scene.
On the surface, is more or less a straightforward romantic drama but reveals itself as a more poignant study of a male-female dynamic.
movie_title: The Middle Of The World (Le milieu du monde) (1975)

movie_review_blurb: Not a whole lot happens in The Midwife, but there's never a dull moment, thanks to the opposing yet equally stellar performances by the two Catherines in the lead.
Maybe Kuso becomes coherent on a second or third viewing, but few would (or should) attempt such torture.
Person to Person is the kind of movie that asks its viewers to open up that tender spot inside. Once you do, it'll completely charm you.
The real horror is, is this a more realistic depiction of the workplace than the comedies that have come before it?
Sadly, the movie ends up playing out like an unmemorable Law & Order episode.
If there's just one takeaway, it's that Aubrey Plaza should be front and center as often as possible.
The film fails to sustain the exhilaration of its initial buildup.
movie_title: Tales Of An Immoral Couple (La Vida Inmoral De La Pareja Ideal) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A film like this needs its people to underline what it means to be human during times of political strife, but with so many bodies shoved inside the van, it's difficult to keep track of who's who and why they're mad.
Though there's always a sense of chaos, with women giving birth and breastfeeding at every turn, Diaz never loses sight of the truth that these are all individuals, not just statistics.
Moments are rousing - especially as Manaury starts to suspect their affair - but we're not given quite enough (particularly from the aloof Julián) for a memorable romance.
Elizabeth inspires empathy, but it often feels like we're being told to feel a certain way by being shown so much rather than being allowed to naturally warm up to her.

Despite its serious subject - the refugee crisis hitting Europe - The Other Side of Hope is also very funny, never losing sight of the droll, comic upside to life, but never making light of tragedy, either.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Coogler and his team have conjured a universe and fleshed out its players, one existing (honestly, thriving) in the even bigger cinematic universe that is Marvel.

Even when most of the subjects have yet to find their happy ending, it's still an uplifting film, and hearing them sing "Somewhere Over the Rainbow," you know that they're still holding out for something better, too.
It's a sometimes impressive effort, but the homage often suggests a photocopy of a photocopy; the skeleton of the inspirational source remains, but the details are obscured.
Moscow Never Sleeps is ambitious to a fault.
A perfectly enjoyable way to spend 81 minutes.
James spins a fascinating and complex web involving lies, fraud, a months-long trial with a hung jury, and cultural biases against Abacus and the immigrant Chinese community it serves.
Siff gives a modest but poignant performance that rings true for women of a certain age and career.
It's a well-meaning portrait, with heartfelt moments - especially as Kim recounts childhood hardships - but it's often muddled, especially in its selection of talking heads.
Herzog's latest narrative feature is a failure of such a baffling degree that it may leave you wondering whether he suffered sunstroke in the desert heat while filming it.
It's certainly an interesting idea, but it's perhaps too ambitious for Vigalondo pull off.
Holy motors! Excuse me while I catch my breath. This is perhaps the fastest and, if not, certainly the most furious of the Fast & Furious movies.
It's a mix of over-the-top violence and humor, but the shtick becomes tiring fast, and even Copley's appeal starts to drag, just as everyone literally drags themselves around as limbs go, one by one.
A diluted interpretation of Aughts torture-porn with a film-student appreciation for Gaspar Noé's color palette, Rupture is a sci-fi abduction thriller that leaves little to be thrilled about.
Is the motion picture Unforgettable trash? Well, yes. But is it the kind of trash you'll have a hell of a time watching at the movie theater? Absolutely.
It's difficult to label Arnow's cinematic voice, and this particular film, or why anyone would even want to watch something so personal, but i hate myself :) is never not fascinating.
A French absurdist comedy that feels wholly original, whether it's your cup of tea or not.
At times filled with mist and awe, and at other times thrillingly heart-racing (arrows-they shoot right at you!), The Lost City of Z feels like a gem dug out from a time capsule.
Davies chooses to mark Dickinson's life story not so much by specific events, but by her character, and Nixon captures the many facets of it with bite and empathy.
I'm still wrapping my head around this film, but I'm not so sure if director James Ponsoldt himself knows what a comedy this is.
Moverman doesn't know what to do with the page-turner source material.
Poitras balances her documentary with a thrilling momentum that's marked by, strangely enough, a sense of humor. A segment where Lady Gaga interviews Julian Assange is not even the weirdest part.
Hounds may be predictable in plot, but it succeeds in making a psychological web of this troubled threesome.

Beautifully animated (we're talking Studio Ghibli standards here), Your Name captures that sensation of waking up from a dream you wish lasted longer, or misplacing a name that's still warm on your tongue, but has just departed.
Wristcutters mostly succeeds with its cleverly posthumous scenario.
Culminates in a tableau that seems to sigh in rumination upon a lost America, land of immigrants.
Like this election cycle, the movie leaves you cynical and weary. We've seen it all before.
Fluffiness aside, the film's multicultural microcosm does have a giddying effect: Tru Loved offers a utopic vision of inclusiveness you wish the world would embrace.

Although Reynolds' script sometimes slips into sentimentality and entertains the odd delusion of grandeur, the film mostly presents a spare, refreshingly clear-eyed depiction of a deadbeat's downward spiral.
Prometheus Triumphant sets lofty goals for itself but fails to find an original entry point or live up to its objectives.
movie_title: Prometheus Triumphant: A Fugue in the Key of Flesh (2009)

movie_review_blurb: As in the minutely observed anatomy of a divorce in The Squid and the Whale, the pleasures and pains of Margot reside in the smallness of scope and queasy focus on delicate family matters.
Although overlong by about 20 minutes, The Secrets mostly handles its subject matter with grace and charm; its heroine's proud defiance even mitigates a questionably celebratory conclusion.
The zany incomprehensibility of the title should serve as fair warning of the quirkfest to come.
Except for the occasional Christopher Walken as Captain Hook oddity, Peter Pan Live! became a dutiful, perfectly fine, surprisingly dull evening of television.
While "Going Clear" is unapologetically one-sided in its dim view of Scientology, the issues it raises ... will make you think about the film long after it's over.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "Montage of Heck" doesn't shock us with any new revelations, but it goes deep - sometimes, uncomfortably so - inside Cobain's messy, restlessly creative, emotionally complex soul.
With its nutty playfulness, 7 Days in Hell is 45 minutes of fast-moving, goofy fun.
By this stage, the joke is beyond played-out.
From the sets and digital effects to Kenny Leon's direction and Fatima Robinson's choreography, the show looked pretty close to ready for Broadway

What keeps Confirmation watchable are vivid performances by a terrific cast. Washington - freed from the overacting mandate that seems part of the Scandal cast playbook - is subtle and moving as Hill.
Killing Reagan, which airs on the National Geographic Channel on Sunday, Oct. 16, feels rushed and incomplete, compressing this historic episode into a flat pancake of pointlessness.
It's a shame The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks wasn't adapted as a miniseries. The amazing true story deserves an adaptation that does justice both to Henrietta Lacks, and to Skloot's achievement.
movie_title: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Wizard of Lies spends much of its overlong two hours and 15 minutes running time repeating how Madoff's crimes victimized members of his family.
Was it respectful? Absolutely. Did it make for kind of a dull, earnest Oscars show. Yeah, kind of.
Robinson lived a historic life. But the achievement of Jackie Robinson is that it shows us the man in full dimension, placing him in rich context.
The whole thing rarely rises above in-jokey parody, and we hardly ever care enough about the characters to feel anything at all.
If only Maloof and Siskel had focused less on gossipy psychological guesswork, and more on Maier's art, this could've been a documentary worthy of its towering subject.
Evans, aided by the leads' rapturous performances, combines violence with tenderness, and thereby captures the complementary, turbulent yet harmonious nature of Kelly and Victor's relationship.
A fun summer movie experience, it's a great ride that gets the season off to a hot start.
It's boring, overly gory and ridiculously executed.
Some of the Kirk vs. Spock scenes I felt were a retread of the first film, but it's a minor bone to pick with an otherwise tremendous sci-fi movie.
It looks great, and it's an impressive tale to bring to the big screen, but the lack of interest in telling the story keep "Gatsby" from being a great film.
Justin Lin takes craziness to new heights and if the audience is willing to suspend disbelief, it's another worthwhile joyride into action-adventure fantasyland.
As a result, Goodman's addition is under-utilized and the film relies too heavily on too few of it's cast. Wait another 6 months to close the book on the Wolfpack when it's available on Netflix.

Some jokes that should have worked fell flat and the movie never sucked me in on a level like a "Toy Story" or "Finding Nemo" would. But if you have kids and are looking for a safe journey to take them on at the movies, "Epic" will punch your ticket.
It's totally juvenile and sophomoric, and the story is simply a humorous background...but it's just so damn funny. A total inside joke that I felt I was inside of.
The suspense and impressive performances make "The East" a thoughtful political thriller worth the time at the box office.

"The Internship" doesn't fail miserably, it just never takes a shot at success. It exists, and as has probably been the fate of many an intern at a huge internet company, it's forgotten about almost immediately.

I didn't hate watching this movie, it held my interest. It's way too long at over two hours, and even if it was a breezy 85 minute joyride, it would still have that fatal flaw: Michael Bay is the guy calling the shots.
This is a fantastic summer movie featuring a superhero that I was so excited to finally see fly back into theaters. "Man of Steel" shows nothing but promise for the future of Superman and DC Comics.
Quick-witted, well-cast and directed with a deft touch, "The Bling Ring" is Sofia Coppola's best work in years.
It is ultimately a kids movie through and through and one I can't wait to show to my kid.
All the neat visuals on Earth can't cover up that this is a movie Will Smith is hoping will make Jaden a star.
It's a shame the story can't live up to the incredible visuals.
You'll definitely feel the 2-plus hours run time, but I was more than happy to do so.

It's not particularly raw or gritty, rather it's as though Disney got their hands on an unbelievable Hollywood script and made the live-action film. Luckily for sports fans and human beings everywhere, these events actually happened.
It's one mystery that will make you yawn and one film that certainly can't lead us out of a dismal year so far at the movies.
"Snitch" can get slow at points but what it lacks in action it makes up for in story, and right now that seems like a fair trade.
Kids will love this, and it's good enough escapism for adults.
There's some cool plot points provided by otherwordly expert J.K. Simmons, but they quickly get lost in the shuffle of a boring movie that feels all too familiar.
The film doesn't hit nearly as hard as it should, and it's a shame that this might be how anyone would spend their 21st birthday.
It certainly has no lack of interesting subject matter, but "Emperor" fails to generate the investment required for such an undertaking.
The evil witches felt forced and one particularly miscast; though all things considered this is a solid fantasy film.

F. Murray Abraham and Armand Assante are criminally underused, but this is an engrossing film that has a well-told story and for that I'd say it makes a good outing at the theater or a great rental option.
Carrey's street magician is funny at times but it feels like he's stuck in a bad Mad TV sketch. Overall, this has all the components of being a great comedy; sadly it just can't pull off the trick.
Olympus should find an audience with all my fellow action movie-loving fans.
It makes even the innocence of an early Britney Spears tune sound dark, dirty and scary.
They have their comedic moments for sure, but too often this movie just feels like something we've seen before, and it ends up just being an average time at the movies.
Whether it's due to the presence of a true star like Brad Pitt or the sheer force of the first 2/3 of the story, "World War Z" is a good time at the movies.
"Retaliation" rescues movie-going audiences from another dull bastardization of our childhood. Yo Joe!
It's a credit to the talents of Alvarez that this gore and violence is a feast for the eyes without seeming unnecessary.
Even if you chuckle occasionally at this, it's hard to see how anyone would want to pay to see it.
As long as everyone is aware that this is a silly cable movie not to be taken seriously, you can fun at this White House.
Monsters fighting robots in the wrong hands can be a gigantic let down but with del Toro at the helm, it becomes the quintessential summer movie experience.
James Badge Dale at least makes the most of his little screen time; couldn't we have had him be the lone ranger?
Even with it's flaws, "Mister and Pete" is anything but a defeat.
movie_title: The Inevitable Defeat of Mister & Pete (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Look, it is as silly as it gets but it's a fun preposterous ride and I was locked in for the whole trip.
One of the better thrill rides to come along in a while.

The pranks themselves, the incredibly deft execution and improvisation (by both Knoxville and his impressive child co-star), and most of all the reactions from the prankees make for some of the best laughs I've had in or out of a theater this year.
You'll get your money's worth with the film alone, but you should probably stay after the credits just to be safe.
Alexander Payne once again proves that he is a director who will always deliver meaningful content in his films.
True love may be worth doing anything to attain, but I can't say "Charlie Countryman" is worth the time investment to learn such a truth.
Director Gavin Hood weaves an excting story adapted from the novel and it was fun to watch an invested Harrison Ford again.
The movements are fluid and intense. The well-paced drama gives way to a tremendous sequences of action, and it's great to see that Francis Lawrence is on-board to direct the next two films.

It's a concept that could easily rely on being a gross-out laugh fest and be satisfied; luckily this movie also includes some heartfelt moments and reveals a side of Vaughn that we haven't seen in his recent fare.
Forget the rating controversy, "Philomena" is a film that can be enjoyed by most everyone and might enjoy a run at Hollywood's most prestigious awards.
The performances are tremendous in "Out of the Furnace", yet the film never is quite able to get out from under a dark cloud of depression.
Another Coen Bros marvel; uncovnentional storytelling, conflicted characters and endings that go against what the audience would perceive as a neat ribbon to the tale we just witnessed.
Telling such a vital story with a scope as broad as it can be, "Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom" is more than just a showcase for great acting; it's a tremendous film experience.

Fans of the cult classic "Old Boy" may have mixed feelings on this new version (or even wonder why it was remade at all), but standing on it's on "Old Boy" is a different type of revenge flick that works just well enough to be fresh.
"Runner Runner" comes up short of being a full house at the movies.
One of the most intense theater-going experiences I've had in years. It is more than just a great movie, it's a giant leap forward for the art of cinema.
The film never became more than an actor showcase, the story seemed too dramatic to be believeable and let down what otherwise is an interesting and sobering reminder of the power of addiction.
This is a band who has done everything there is to do in the world of music; they took a bold risk with this new style directed by Nimrod Antal.

As a parent it's a welcome addition to a library of movies that both me and my daughter can enjoy; whether she will fully grasp the good vs. evil storyline is one thing. Us both falling out of seats laughing at the minions is the guarantee.
Is Safe Haven a good movie? N. Will you take your girlfriend to see it anyway? Yep. So enjoy the good moments and try not to laugh outloud during the rest.
I'm not the horror lover in Schmoes Know, but "The Conjuring" isn't just a great horror film, it's a great time at the movies.
"Fruitvale Station" will emotionally move you and simultaneously make you appreciate the filmmaking abilities of Ryan Coogler and Michael B. Jordan.
For all the visual flair and incredible talents of it's director, "Elysium" just wouldn't allow me to get past the message it continues to preach over and over again.
Didn't we get past this type of CGI in the mid-90's??
It never shifts into third gear as a great comedy but there are worse places to be stuck than in second with this family.
It's great to see a supporting cast that consists of comedy heavyweights Jane Curtin, Bill Burr and newcomer Adam Ray.
Didn't this man have a family? Battle cancer? Innovate more than just home computers?

Those familiar with the source material (or looking for a post-Twilight obsession) may enjoy the quick pace of the film and be able to keep up; however for the rest of us "Mortal Instruments" is just another ordinary book adaptation.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The "Home Alone" of horror movies! Prepare accordingly and you shouldn't be disappointed.
We get it, the cops in Bulgaria need some more on-road training. Pass.
"Closed Circuit" peters out too early to be truly memorable, but the film is nevertheless an entertaining legal at a time when theaters could use something good to sell.

The clear talent in this cast is Diesel and Sackhoff, but while Vin gets his star due I felt that Sackhoff was underused. The problems in Riddick never subjugate the enjoyment of a sci-fi ride that should help re-energize fans of Pitch Black.
Kids should be entertained by the visuals, and adults can at least take solace in the fact that they're in a dark theater where no one can catch them snoozing. Just make sure you're not a snorer.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: "Don Jon" proves that Joseph Gordon-Levitt is one of the best and most versatile actors working today, and shows promise for a future behind the camera as well.
All things considered this is a movie you enjoy on cable and then probably forget about.
Die Hard 5 does at least feature the best villain in the franchise: director John Moore.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: I was hooked in early and was in this film's grip throughout. If "Side Effects" is any indication, Soderbergh is hanging it up way too soon.
If you missed it in theaters the first time, it's probably going to be the best movie theater experience you'll have so far this year.
Christopher Nolan, does he tie up the trilogy well? Damn right he does. He pulls great moments from the source material, gives his own spin and wraps up this trilogy with a bang.
I think some people who see this will buy Rashida Jones and Andy Samberg as a couple more than I did. I liked them better when they were apart and looking for new love.
The first half of this movie might make you laugh but it's very sloppy. I saw this a few months ago when it was a much better film called Attack the Block.

It is fun but Arnold enthusiasts might nitpick it to the point of no return and it is understandable. It is nothing new, follows the same beats but I thought it was a nice rendition. I still don't understand why it was made.

In the original Bourne series it was "fight fight fight/story story story." It had that balance. This one has a lot of talking for a long time. We get the point, and then they keep talking and talking...let's have a fight already.

There's a lot of laughs to be found in this movie, a few scenes in particular I was laughing so hard I had tears in my eyes. There are slow moments but who cares? All I'll say is get ready for the scene with Zach and his family at the dinner table.

I had a lot of fun with this movie, I got exactly what I expected. You're gonna get some good one-liners, some bad ones, some laughs when it's supposed to be serious. But If you are going in expecting The King's Speech, shame on you.

It almost got me, it almost did. The overall storyline had promise, but this film just didn't quite have that magic touch that it could have. I was expecting forrest Gump meets D.A.R.Y.L and instead I got- Who cares with Leaves.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The script is terrible and the greatMichael Shannon is forced to sound like a 1930's gangster: "Hey what's the big idea!" and he's so over the top and it sucks you out of it.
If you go in expecting full-on action you may be disappointed, but I did enjoy both the action and the slower beats, and for that I'm giving this 4/5 Schmoes.

It was as funny as I remember and brilliant because it is subtle. It just knocks it out of the park. I love everything about this movie, one of my favorite Pixar movies of all time, 5/5 Schmoes. The new sound/3D adds to the greatness that is Nemo.

It moves a little slow, but for me it had me from the get-go. I wanted to know what's gonna happen next; surprised when the film took it's various turns and it made me realize that I never wanna be this rich, way too much responsibility.

Hoffman really brings this Lannister Dodd character to life. He's a magnet, the kind of guy who walks into a room full of 100 people and he instantly gets everyone's attention. As always though, P.T. Anderson is the star.

I loved this film because it reminded me of watching an old school action film with the special effects of today. Movies like RoboCop or The Crow, I like that tone a lot and so to me I had a ball with it.

The real thing to focus on here is the chemistry between Gylenhaal and Michael Pena; it's authentic. The action is god but it's the scenes with them in the car that really help you understand them and their viewpoints.

The first part of this movie really worked. It was the right amount of intensity....and then it gets a little silly, the tone gets jumbled, and the end of the film was the definition of a cop out. That being said, much better than W and Wallstreet 2

The biggest problem with this movie is the relationship between Eastwood and his daughter Adams. They keep having these scenes where she wants to heal their relationship but he backs off, and it's so repetitive, she runs away. This happens five times.
If you are a Katy Perry fan, you love her and everything about her, you should have fun with this movie. If you don't care about her, Ted is still out in theaters.

People who are so caught up on it being a reboot need to get over it. It stands on its own as a superhero film. It may take a while for the action to get going, but once it does, it is the most true adaptation we have seen of the web slinger to date.
It truly is a good movie that will get the audience sucked in; however the tone that David O. Russell has been able to inject into his films takes surprisingly long to surface here.

It is a little overly ambitious and now that you mention it, reminds me of Funny People, it starts off as one thing and goes into all these different tones and you (taps wrist) come on guys people have lives to live.

If you go to Wikipedia and type in 'summer blockbuster', this is the movie that should come up. It is everything that you need in a summer film. It kicks the season off perfectly and you will feel like a little kid again.
There's some laughs in this movie, there's some action, but halfway through this movie it just takes this weird turn, and you're like 'what happened to all the fun that I was having in this theater?'
This movie is not horrendous and judging from the trailers we've seen, I guess that's a win?

Nobody's waddling into this theater by accident. You need to walk into this theater expecting to see a bunch of babies, some pregnant chicks, a bunch of clueless dudes and when you do that, you kind of have fun because it's not a bad movie.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: I don't blame the acting, I blame the directing. Obviously from watchig the trailers you know something has happened as a result of the nuclear incident and the explanation for what is just 'eh...blah...who cares?
I think you're invested in this movie from the moment it starts. It is a little inconsistent but overall I had fun with it. But no, Kristen Stewart is not fairer than Charlize Theron. FAN TA SY

Whether you have kids, will never have kids, have to take your nephews, your nieces, or some random kid, you're gonna be able to get though this movie. There is a lot of fun stuff in here for everyone.
If you are a fan of the MIB franchise, you should enjoy this movie. It's a bit cartoony at times but overall it is a fun ride.
You will believe you are on another planet, visually it is fantastic. I wanted to love this movie but I wound up just liking it. That being said, I can't wait for another one

After Jack and Jill there's nowhere to go but up. Adam Sandler is his own genre. You know where the laughs are coming from and exactly where it's going. You have to choose whether you're going to hate it or just go with it.

It is a fine movie but it wasn't as witty, clever or funny as the other Pixar movies...and I wanted the lead character Mereda to be memorable like Belle from Beauty and the Beast or Ariel from the mermaid movie. and she's just not...she's forgettable.

This movie just made Steven Spielberg's life easier because his Lincoln biopic coming out in December wil definitely be the better of these two films. This could have been fun, it never settles in what it wants to be and ultimately fails.

Pop culture reference heaven. I haven't laughed this hard at a movie in a while. It's the funniest movie of the year so far. I'm happy to see Seth MacFarlane take such a great first step on the big screen. You saved every one of us!
Females rejoice! Your Avengers is here!
Jeremy Irons, Emma Thompson and an under-used Viola Davis all lend some credibility to what could have otherwise become a laughable farce.

Logan Lerman makes you completely forgive and forget Percy Jackson. You are with him from start to finish in this fantastic adaptation. This is a very popular book that I think will be a popular film because it just does everything right.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: I got very emotional during certain scenes because of Victor and Sparky's relationship. They have such a great relationship and dog lovers will definitely feel that connection the whole time. Burton's best movie since Big Fish.
I feel like the 48 frames per second took off a full half point of enjoyment, yet I proudly reclaim here as I confidently send movie lovers forth to see "The Hobbit" (in 24 frames, please!).
All the Tarantino hallmarks are there: engaging story, hilarious dialogue, shocking violence and exciting musical accompaniment.
While it's only drawback may be it's lack of abiity to win over reluctant viewers, "Les Miserables" has so much to offer a fan of musical cinema that it easily is one of the best films of 2012.
One of the films that should not fly under the radar of sports comedy fans, "The Hammer" is a surprising good time at the movies.
What could have been "LA Confidential" ends up being a dime store "Untouchables" crossed with "Dick Tracy".
Seeing a flick in January usually means lowering your expectations, but no moviegoer should have to endure this.
It never gets that exciting, slows down with unnecessary plot points, and isn't anything more than a breezy Saturday afternoon cable movie.
It's silly, and if you're not a fan of classic Arnold you might find this one to be pointless...but that's not me at all. Arnold is back, and his legion of fans won't be disappointed.
An original story that just can't live up to the promise of it's ambition, "John Dies at the End" just isn't that good of a movie.
Some promise was there, but "Hansel and Gretel" is ultimately just another January bore that we'll forget by March.
It just doesn't pay off the way it should, mainly because the gags are built on cheap laughs and the shock value of seeing famous people get dirty.
Statham is ever-reliable as a leading tough guy, but he gets saddled with the unwinnable task of teaming up with a silly, unnecessary sidekick played by Jennifer Lopez.
Throw in Alan Arkin and this would seem to be a promising premise, but the dialogue didn't click and the film just meanders through it's one evening.

Jason Mamoa also impressed me as the villain; all his sins for "Conan the Barbarian" are forgiven and hopefully the climactic axe fight will prove to Stallone that we have a new Expendable cast member the next time around.
The two have palpable chemsitry, but the film's hyper pace keeps pushing them forward when it might have nicer to just let these two make us laugh
What you ultimately take away from this movie is that it is not a commercialized propoganda piece; it's simply one of the most honest, intense and best films experiences of 2012.

Why are the bad guys going after him at all? They know what he can do. Just avoid him; if you do go after him don't kidnap his family, you just kill them. Morons. Oh, and then Maggie Grace throws grenades off the roof.
This could be a film that will suck you in if it's on your tv on a lazy Saturday afternoon, but I have U-verse. I'm sure something better will be on one of those other channels.
This is 40......minutes too long.

Just fantastic all around the board. Affleck paints a great picture, and I'll tell you what. 1980's Iran? Scarier than Jurassic Park. One of the best of the year, 4.5/5 Schmoes. Will be nominated for Best Picture.

It's not about the character development so much in this film as it is the people and the crazy scenarios they get involved with. Mostly see it for the stand-out performances of Sam Rockwell and Christopher Walken.

When you first hear about this film just don't think it's gonna work. But Kevin James got himself into shape and he's a huge fan of the UFC. As on the nose as it is, it pays a ton of respect to the sport and that comes through.
Yuck. We are one step away from doing "Paranormal Activity in Space."
I was confused because I didn't know which story linked to which. Maybe I'm the dummy, but it felt like a mess. A sloppy soup that was good at first but became way too much to handle.
It's a great dynamic and it works but my favorite character isn the whole thing was Alan Tudyck as King Candy, such a hilarious throwback to the Mad Hatter from Alice in Wonderland.
Denzel is so vulnerable and damaged in this movie, and that's what makes it a stand-out performance.
This mess makes no sense and plods along for 90 minutes throwing things at us that are neither scary nor contributing to the tale.
We get the gadgets, the nods to previous Bond films, the martinis and all but "Skyfall" succeeds by not resting on its veritable history but by adding more depth to the celebrated franchise.
A solid cast delivers in a movie that is thoroughly enjoyable if not consistently great.

While I can see some audience members who weren't prepared for this story getting restless or even bored, I was captivated by the performances and see this as another historical win for Steven Spielberg.
It is nothing short of jaw dropping what the audience is treated to on-screen, and the 3D element works well the some of the most incredible images ever seen in movies.
The story let me down from time to time; it's when we get to see the master work at his craft that "Hitchcock" delivers the most.

The movie succeeds in it's comparison of the 2008 economic crisis to the scaling back of wages for even the jobs we wish didn't exist. It is a bit slow and dialogue heavy and because of that I ended up merely liking it when I wanted to love it.
Josh Peck is terribly miscast in this role and his character is so annoying, he almost made me root for North Korea.
Other than some of the King George/FDR interactions I felt like this movie was little more than a silly soap opera.

Peter Jackson and his team have certainly taken artistic license to extend these films beyond the Tolkein novels, and if Hobbit fans are willing to accept that, they are in for a tremendous adventure with "The Desolation of Smaug".
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: While it may not be anything you need to rush out to the theaters to see, "Homefront" is a solid action film that, thanks to the talents of Statham, can venture into a more dramatic side other kick-ass movies have to stay away from.
Sure, it's aimed at kids, but as much as they all love dinosaurs...subjecting them to a film this annoying won't do anything but dampen that enthusiasm.
Alfonso Gomez-Rejon has directed a touching movie that will indeed tug on your heartstrings, but in such a unique way that it feels like the very first time.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A documentary worth watching for racing fans, film buffs or anyone else looking for an engaging time at the movies.
movie_title: Winning: The Racing Life Of Paul Newman (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Certainly worth the price of admission for the laughs, but we could've used more in the last third of the film.

Poking fun at itself while still treating it's subject matter with respect is no easy task, but the stars handle it magnificently. "Ant-Man" is one of the most unexpectedly fun rides you can have in the MCU...or anywhere else for that matter.

Cameos galore ensue, most notably by LeBron James and John Cena...both athletes show a surprising amount of comedic chops. Colin Quinn, Brie Larson and an almost unrecognizable Tilda Swinton all deliver great supporting turns as well
The performances are great, and Allen sits back and let's the stars do the work this time around. Not for everyone, but "Irrational Man" might just surprise viewers not expecting to care.
"Southpaw" gives movie fans what they want: great performances and an emotional core that will resonate even with non-boxing fans.
The newest installment in Tom Cruise's franchise might be the best yet.
The jokes comes out swinging, but virtually every scene is set up basically to get us with a gross-out gag that echoes the more recent (and less funny) Farrelly Brothers efforts.
"The Visit" shouldn't have anyone shouting from the rooftops that M. Night Shyamalan is back to his A-game...but it at least stops the blood-letting from his last decade of career wounds.

Some of the cut-aways get tiresome, but all can be forgiven once the legendary Mel Brooks shows up for an extended role. It won't contend for Best Animated Movie of 2015, but it should make for a fun time at the movies this Halloween.
We'll never get to see Cage as Superman, but with "The Death of 'Superman Lives'...What Happened?" Jon Schnepp masterfully portrays a universe where we did.
movie_title: The Death of Superman Lives: What Happened? (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "99 Homes" can't live up to it's early promise...but it's still worth seeing for Shannon and Garfield, two of the best actors on the market today.
The film is overwrought with visuals that at best are hit-and-miss, and his actors all seem to be in a different movie.
It's more than just a return to form for Pixar; "Inside Out" might be one the best films they've ever made.
If you've never seen the show, check out the flick then have fun on HBO Go. Oh yeah.

With a run time that is well over two hours and probably didn't have to be; you can clearly see that Bay is still in love with slow-motion and low sweeping shots. That being said, Bay has made a good film.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It can't be the amazing revelation the first film was, but "Jurassic World" is a great amusement park ride...and the best sequel to it's predecessor we've had.

The audience feels transported to this post-apocalyptic setting, and the mind-blowing action sequences rival any that have ever been put to film. George Miller does a magnificent job in recapturing the feel of his beloved "Mad Max" franchise.
No one is particularly interesting here, and unfortunately the fate of "Blackhat" is the same that has befallen many a January action flick: it's a miss.
This is a film that should have gone direct to Cinemax.
"Kingsman" is not for the faint of heart and features some intense violenece, but it's delightful tone makes even the most sinister of acts feel like they can be avenged with a smile.

Once the real game begins, the humor starts to miss and the plot points get ridiculously unbelievable. While Smith shows flashes of his classic charisma, Robbie is under-used and no one else is around to step up and make us care.
It hits all the predictable moments one might expect, but the solid acting jobs and incredible true story make "McFarland, USA" a credible sports movie that will certainly brighten your spirits.
Jackman and Patel are largely wasted in their one-note roles, and you'll barely notice Sigourney Weaver
Going through the motions and never uncovering any funny material to play with, "Unfinished Business" is just that: a film that had loads of potential but isn't able to muster any laughs with it.
One of the early surprises of 2015, and hopefully will expand to more theaters and the wider audience it deserves.
The visuals didn't feel realistic enough to engage and overall "Insurgent" is a let down. Unless you're a hard core fan of the novels upon which it's based, I'd wait for cable.
It misleads audiences hoping for a girtty action thriller and ends up being a huge disappointment.
We know this movie is going to try to pull out our heartstrings, but "Danny Collins" manages to take few unexpected turns, and it makes us want to join it for the entire trip.

It does manage to pick up the pace in the third act and actually get us somewhat invested, but by that time we've already seen too much. It's certainly watchable, but best to wait until it's free to do so.
The chemistry amongst our heroes is once again terrific to watch, and the action sequences deliver both thrills and laughs.
It makes The Other Woman look like Ex-Machina.
It's a slow burn here, and occasionally it flirts with boredom, but "Maggie" still is a worthy endeavor for fans to see a new side of the legendary Arnold Schwarzenneger.
It's not a disaster by any means, it's simply just a sequel that could have been better, but couldn't quite find the pitch.
The bear and the Brown family get a fair amount of real laughs and also manage to weave a touching story.
Overall, "The Light Between Oceans" is a fine representation of the film-making potential of director Derek Cianfrance...although it won't be mentioned among his career highlights.
An entertaining enough ride, and one I think my daughter will definitely enjoy soon.
A really honest, real depiction of what it's like growing up.
I'm enjoying the chemistry here, but I don't know if I love the movie as much.
There were times when I could see the brilliance of Spielberg and there were other times where I felt like I was maybe expecting just a little bit more.
If you aren't interested in this stuff, it might lose you. [Gary Oldman] is engaging, there's no doubt about it, but the subject matter could lose you.
It's incredible from start to finish. I could watch it again, I want to show other people.
movie_title: Jim & Andy: The Great Beyond - Featuring a Very Special, Contractually Obligated Mention of Tony Clifton (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's handled in such a way that the characters become very lovable.
Should you see it? My answer: hell yes

He is just getting better and better and knows how to develop characters in this emotional way that you're invested...this guy is a rising star. As great as every single actor is in this movie, Ryan Coogler, once again, is the star of this film.
I believe that the characters are real. It was a pleasant surprise.
It's a heightened version of a Cinemax movie in the mid 90's.
The visuals in this film--it will kick your face in it's so gorgeous.
Sometimes it got a little too zany, but then it came back down and it was pretty funny.
It's not a good movie. It's a badly executed movie.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It is raw, and it can be disturbing, but it's a brave, brave film.
Ava DuVernay was using her talents the best she could there, but I don't think there was enough in the finalized script...this particular story didn't hit me.
It's two and half hours but it certainly doesn't feel like it.
A worthy tribute to the original 1960 classic, and it's a great ride for fans of action or westerns.
I had a lot of fun with this movie, I really did laugh out loud.
None of it made sense. The whodunit, who is it. Speed did a better job of giving me the characters on the bus.
I highly recommend Moana to virtually any audience.
One of the great films of 2016.
Live By Night is a flat misfire, and one that hopefully a director such as Affleck can make up for with the upcoming Batman film.
Peter Berg and Mark Whalberg are back together again, and once more they do a commendable job bringing a true story to life.
The 24 Hour War doesn't just tell us the story of an incredible rivalry... it puts us in the driver seat.
This is a movie that should be seen featuring a story that needed to be told.
I can't say that I'd recommend Underworld: Blood Wars to anyone but the hardest of core fans.
Split does a terrific job of keeping us guessing and never allowing the audience to relax for too long; there's also some of the best humor Shyamalan has ever put on screen.
What begins as a promising tale of adventure devolves into a sleepy grasp at historical fiction that won't land on anyone's must-see list.

There is certainly plenty of fun to be had with James Gunn's new entry in the Guardians universe, and I will look forward to more adventures with this group...but Volume 2 didn't quite hit the right note for me.
It's so great to see a film pay off in a way that will please both its hardcore fans and a general public that has been clamoring for it for decades.
Overall Justice League is a fun action ride that gives us great introductions to new heroes and solid chemistry within the team.
Del Toro once again shines and gets the most out of his amazing cast... Sally Hawkins leads an incredible ensemble in one of the most imaginative, emotional films of the year.

A deep and complex journey into discovery, Call Me By Your Name is an announcement that Timothee Chalamet is a new force to be reckoned with in cinema. Certainly a top contender for awards this season!
Rian Johnson has made a Star Wars movie that features so many great additions to canon and mythological intrigue that will have fans buzzing for years.
I love this movie.
A serviceable job of depicting the amazing true story of a true hero but the movie can't live up to the story it was hoping to tell.
The beasts are fun, the magic exciting and the story engaging. We're off to another good start in this universe.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Woods gives a game effort but can't quite sustain it's own momentum.

It's acceptable for young 20-somethings to be getting hammered night after night dealing with heartbreak, but these two are in their 40's. Maybe they need to hit a meeting somewhere instead? Aside from that this is decent remake.

The performances are fine (even with Keifer Sutherland's silly accent) and Kit Harrington has the makings of a movie star...but while "Pompeii" showed promise early, this disaster film ends up being just another disaster.

movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A work of haunting power.
Asian horror fans may be intrigued by the premise of this, but they should resist.
This is a terrific premise for a movie. Too bad they do so little with it.
Movies based on video games continue to earn their wretched reputation, and I'm afraid The Angry Birds Movie won't do anything to change that.

Jeremiah Tower: The Last Magnificent does give a haunting portrait of its protagonist whose tormented background gave him a vision of creating a place above the concerns of the ordinary world, buoyed by his culinary creations.
I laughed out loud enough times to recommend this retread.
If The Circle isn't the biggest disappointment of the moviegoing spring, it's up there.
This comic tragedy isn't something that'll blow you away, but I can't stop admiring the neat turns that this thing takes.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Alien: Covenant washed over me and left me thinking, "Eh."
Pretty deep stuff from a popcorn picture, and it's one reason why the movie theaters right now are such a rich vein of entertainment.
This is a proper introduction to a superhero who was brought on so lamely in Batman vs. Superman, and the good outweighs the bad here, on balance.
Instead of trying to expand the Cars universe, this third installment brings its cocky hero face to face with his sporting mortality and finds an emotional wellspring that brings up some good things.
It's chilling in its implications. Were it as chilling an experience, this would be a truly great horror film.

Spider-Man: Homecoming benefits from its small scale and its focus on Peter's day-to-day teenage existence. The Marvel movies could use more of this.
And now I've found the romantic comedy of the summer and perhaps the year.
As a spy thriller, this is riddled with problems... As an action flick, though, this is stellar.

[Jürgen Hinzpeter] is one of the world's greatest actors, and watching him work is more than enough reason to recommend A Taxi Driver.

His [Taylor Sheridan's] first directing effort doesn't rise to the level of those other two movies, but it's solid genre entertainment all the same.

This quick-and-dirty free-for-all is the cinematic equivalent of a chocolate fudge cake slathered in maple-bacon ice cream. You don't order it because it's good for you. You order it because you crave it. Free Fire will satisfy your craving.

I don't look forward to Mike Birbiglia's films, but whenever I see them, I find I like them.
Kusama does an expert job of unspooling the suspense.

Committed performances by the two actresses help make this uniquely unnerving.
The reasons to see this are Na's expert buildup of sickening dread.
Whatever your beliefs might be, it will make you think.
Inconsequential but insightful drama about funny people.
If I were Zack Snyder, I'd be ashamed. Since I'm not, I'm amused.

Overstuffed and undernourished.
Precisely because it addresses fears that have been absent from horror movies, Get Out is a future classic.
Logan is a beautiful send-off for the proud, tormented warrior who was so recognizably human underneath his claws.

Boyle and his characters have a few more wrinkles and regrets now, but they haven't lost their rowdy energy and wit, qualities that keep the electricity going in T2 Trainspotting.

. . . incessant hustling and crackbrained scheming makes Good Time into an undeniably riveting spectacle.
After all, the meditative, mystical Darren Aronofsky who made The Fountain and Noah is all well and good, but I much prefer the face-melting, bad-acid-trip, this-movie-is-eating-my-brain Aronofsky.
Regardless, this is the best figure skating movie ever made (sorry, Blades of Glory), even if it's more likely to inspire little girls to flip the bird than take to the ice.
Spielberg demonstrates marvelous skill as he follows through on the story's journalistic, legal, political, and economic consequences.

movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Melanie Lynskey is the best reason to see this black comedy as a put-upon nursing assistant who snaps at the world after her house is burglarized and takes the law into her own hands.
movie_title: I don't feel at home in this world anymore. (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The weirdness on display is engrossing, and the film already has a Criterion Collection DVD release.

This Korean action-thriller is more everything than the John Wick films and Atomic Blonde put together.
The results are astonishing.
As a vehicle for its lead actress, it's satisfactory, but no more.

Between this ambitious epic's genuine accomplishments and its injection of color into Madeleine L'Engle's beloved fantasy novel, I really, really hate having to pronounce it a failure. Yet that's what I must do.
Never less than pleasant to be around.
Molly's Game is so thoroughly worked out that its drama never gets going, because neither its characters nor you have any chance to take a breath.
The pandering to modern sensibilities left me feeling insulted, and it would be enough to derail a better movie than this.
... a complete dud.

... Lady Macbeth, under its Victorian petticoats, cuts savagely close to the bone.
Real life sucks, especially its misogyny. Fortunately, this is not only the greatest tennis film ever made but also a rousing piece of entertainment.

It all makes for a rousing piece of historical drama.
... this film is an entrancing glimpse of the odd forms that love can take.

Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull is quite a bit of fun.

movie_review_blurb: [Andrzej Wajda] didn't make this horror film, but his spirit hangs over it.
The depth of feeling he brings to The Dark Knight Rises raises the bar yet again.
In the final tally, I found enough enjoyment here to make this expensive ride worth it. Shame about the end, though.

From the corporate logo depicting the iconic superheroes to the supervillain's flying robot army to the post-credits sequence, Justice League takes its lead from The Avengers, and the comparison does not flatter the current film.

Good news, everyone: We found the role that James Franco was born to play.

Wonderstruck is a shining addition...
Another Żuławski extravaganza of overacting.

movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's graphic and highly stylized violence that still has the power to shock even four decades later.
The Phenom starts with the germ of a promising idea, but its creator can't take it beyond that.
There's still some gas left in the tank here.
Any movie that works as a spy thriller, love story, and horror movie all at once is pretty remarkable. You might say it takes a fair amount of wizardry.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This is the ingenuity and warmth we love in Pixar movies, and long may it remain.

Compared to films like Henry Selick's James and the Giant Peach and Wes Anderson's Fantastic Mr. Fox that got the essence of Dahl right, The BFG comes off as a sadly inadequate flight of fancy from storytellers we expected better from.
The blockbuster sequels and remakes may be dominating the multiplexes like in every June, but there are original stories to see if you look for them, and this one may well be the best one right now.
It's not deep, and it's certainly not as worked out an animal fable as Zootopia, but it's funny and inoffensive, and I think I'll be watching it again before I see Finding Dory.
The comic riches here are enough to make this movie a fairer version of Wedding Crashers for our decade, a recommendation you can take all the way to the altar.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: [The] result isn't as much fun as the Iron Man movies, but it's better than The Incredible Hulk and a worthy entry in the fast-growing Avengers series.

Spider-Man 3 probably would have been better as two focused 80-minute films. The ambitious, overstuffed, and complicated 139-minute one that we have isn't as well-proportioned as its predecessor, but it's full of canny insights and bits that ring true.
Kung Fu Panda is not as much fun as Kung Fu Hustle, but it's much better than Kung Pow: Enter the Fist.

They do get the right actresses for this, though. All three of these women contribute worthy reactions and riffs, though the straw that stirs this drink is Hahn, who is so underappreciated that it's no longer funny.
As either an effects-heavy comedy or a laugh-heavy sci-fi thriller, this is better than much of what I've seen this summer.

Patsy and Edina should have been left in their decade, where we could imagine them partying it up and smoking weird substances with the Spice Girls and Liam Gallagher. Bringing them out now does no favors to them or us.
Stewart, however, infuses the part with softness and vulnerability that pop the role into three dimensions. She's easily the best reason to see this otherwise flat entry into Allen's body of work.

This movie is afraid of making too much fun of its subject for this and other reasons, and that unfortunately keeps the movie from joining that great tradition of films that pay tribute to the cracked nobility of making bad art.

The near-feral child at the center of this movie puts it on the same turf as the remake of The Jungle Book, but Pete's Dragon is a better film in almost every way, and it succeeds where The BFG notably failed.
Refn's style is worth sampling even though it feels in search of a subject.
J.J. Abrams' restart of the famous saga is a slick, well-produced piece of entertainment that blows the cobwebs off the venerable series.
Up is funny, heartfelt, and never less than entertaining.
If nothing else, this big brain-teaser of a movie is a great conversation piece.
A nice summer treat.
The X-Men series has found some promising new blood in front of the camera, but it's sorely in need of some behind it as well.
Lady Susan is infuriating in her ability to justify whatever she wants to do and you want all her romantic plans to fail, but Beckinsale nevertheless makes her into delightful company.
It's remorseless and pure and unlike anything you've ever seen before, and it's now playing near you if you're adventurous enough to take the plunge.
A Bigger Splash is cutting social satire in a manner familiar from decades of Italian cinema. The sexiness and star power here help it all go down easily.
You won't soon forget the way that one ends.
Well, if you're going to see only one comic-book superhero movie this summer, X-Men: Days of Future Past looks like your best bet.
Thankfully, the sequel pulls a nice surprise of its own: being a vast improvement on the original.

Why in the world do the filmmakers go to the trouble of casting Rosario Dawson and Rosie Perez as the detectives' significant others and then leave them in the States away from all the hijinks?
The sweet, blissful buzz that accompanies the end of this comedy masterpiece will make you feel like you've just watched your own best friend get happily married.

Some of the other entries in this series haven't been short on humor, but this is the first one where the humor is pretty much the whole point of the science-fiction extravaganza. It proves to be a nice change.
The World's End is not only the season's funniest movie but also its best action thriller, its best addiction drama, and its best movie about the apocalypse.

Much of the movie is genuinely entertaining, but some of it betrays the same desperation that you find in bad animated flicks, as the filmmakers keep things loud, fast, and colorful in the hope that the smallest audience members won't get bored.
The results are decidedly underwhelming despite a deluxe cast.
I wish it had done more than just include lots of shots of people looking reverentially up in the sky, but it does open up some promising avenues for the series going forward.
Where's the coiled, fuming, cigar-chomping, sarcastic quip-firing killing machine from the first two X-Men movies? I want that guy back. He was fun.
This movie left me feeling warm and glowy inside, which is a pretty neat trick for a subversive, blood-soaked superhero action film.
[Liman] reminds you that he was put on this earth to make popcorn thrillers. The ingenuity he brings to this disposable project is a sign of why Hollywood blockbusters continue to rule the globe.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Kubo and the Two Strings is a visual feast. If only its storytelling had kept up, it would be another masterpiece from this animation studio.
Irresponsible and overinflated though it is, Inglourious Basterds is still more pleasurable than half a dozen Defiances and Valkyries and Miracle at St. Annas put together.

Allied aims for the epic sweep and tragic grandeur of old-school romances, but it just winds up looking old.
The result is a slow-acting poison pill of a movie, brutal and effective.
Liz is most in control of herself when she's at her most self-destructive, and she is mesmerizing to watch.
The studios announced that Rogue One will be a stand-alone affair without any sequels or spin-offs, which is just as well. There's nothing here that's worth carrying into future movies.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While [Longergan] retains his playwright's focus on the writing and acting elements of film, he's skilled enough as a cinematic storyteller that this leisurely paced 137-minute movie does not drag or suffer from any dead spots.
The result is enough to make you leap out of your seat and punch the air in triumph.

It's incredible that it has taken this long to put an August Wilson play on the screen. This movie redresses that, and its performances are wholly worthy of such a quintessentially American playwright. We're privileged to have them.
It turns out all the charisma in the world can't save your film if it's confused about what it's supposed to be.
All this star power and musical talent in the voice cast is great. It should have gone for more.

It's incredible that it has taken this long to put an August Wilson play on the screen. This movie redresses that, and its performances are wholly worthy of such a quintessentially American playwright. We're privileged to have them.

You'll need a pair of hip waders to make your way through the clichés that the actors have to spout: You Can't Trust Anyone, No One Gets Away Clean, and Live It Up Because There Is No God Anyway.

What I realized watching this was how much the Potter movies relied on the skill and charisma of Daniel Radcliffe, Emma Watson, and Rupert Grint. The actors here are introducing new characters from scratch, and so far they're not that gripping.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's one of the best things you'll see all year.
This well-intentioned film is so bound up in cotton wool that it doesn't have the impact its story deserves.
This nasty, perverted, and highly enjoyable erotic thriller is the most ferocious movie about matters of the heart since Dangerous Liaisons.

It's shot through with the same sordid desperation as the best movies of its type, and that quality looks different when it's seen through a woman's eyes. That makes Equity a valuable thing to have.

[It's] a valuable reconstruction of the events leading up to the oil-rig disaster that led to countless losses in human and marine life. The trouble is, that's all it is, and it feels less like a necessary narrowing of scope than a failure of imagination.
Without [Adams], Arrival becomes an arid and talky exercise, but thanks to her remarkable efforts, this thoughtful science-fiction epic has human warmth at its core.

movie_review_blurb: What saves this movie is Gordon-Levitt's subtle and profound performance as a political conservative being torn apart by his ingrained loyalty to his country and his moral convictions about the bad things that he's doing.
You should always be suspicious of homeless dramas that star Oscar-nominated Hollywood actors.
Queen of Katwe is that rare movie about Africa that doesn't involve war or disease or any other kind of large-scale death, and these performances help this remarkable story earn its uplift honestly.

Watchable but no more than that.
Hacksaw Ridge does justice to the courage and conscience of this man of nonviolence. This could have been a great film at 100 minutes or so. Too bad it runs 131.
This outback revenge fantasy wrapped in haute couture costumes is a good deal of fun.

You may not know who Andrea Arnold is, but she's a genius.
A top-heavy, tasteful, overstuffed film.
I do have a professional duty to render my opinion on The Birth of a Nation as a work of dramatic art. As such, it's an impressive and confident debut for a first-time filmmaker.

While the movie shines at times, its surprisingly stale storyline keeps it from becoming an instant, stop-motion classic.
This movie will make you happy, for 80 minutes at least.

The poetic visuals create a disorienting sense of being at once immersed in the characters' world and kept at a distance.

[Andrea] Arnold has a knack for subtle details but also for portraying female characters whose natural warmth and energy have been muted by trauma or social isolation.

As Piotr says in Dekalog: Five: "Everyone wonders if what they do has any meaning. I'm afraid that that meaning gets harder and harder to find." Dekalog challenges us to search for it in a complex world.

There are no flying saucers in the great Russian director's haunting tale of a journey into the depths of a postapocalyptic landscape, but it offers visual splendor, as well as mysteries, portents and miracles.
"Beauty and the Beast" remains a profound exploration of the human and animal worlds, light and darkness, and love and art.

movie_review_blurb: While [Lynne] Ramsay's sensibility is entirely her own, it approaches the rawness of work by Nan Goldin or Richard Billingham.
Beneath the antic plot and sentimental portrayal of her marriage is a moving portrait of a woman who searches for an audience and loses herself.

Throughout Sixty Six, Klahr unleashes a dazzling array of visual ideas, deftly combined with sounds, silence, or music and all in the service of what he calls the film's "pop associational mindscape."

[Christian] Mungiu has taken a leap forward into bold, focused storytelling.
This surprising little sleeper will give you more big feelings in its first 15 minutes than every one of last summer's blockbusters combined.
A darkly pleasing, sometimes surreal parable shot through with thoroughly Russian attitude - and humor.

A fluffed-up documentary that sticks it to the already famously flawed author without providing much revelation.

Tries so hard and gets so much right that you can't help but root for it, even though the casts' line delivery never lets you forget they're acting.

[Soloway] excels at drawing out nuances in female friendship. Here, though, she promises an uncomfortable exposé of middle-class morality, then doesn't follow through.

movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "Into the Storm" quickly spirals downward into a vortex of vapidity.
So much star power packed together in one place hasn't produced such a cheesy result since the recording of "We Are the World."
A quirky spirit pervasive throughout and great supporting cast, including Anna Kendrick, make it a semi-satisfying "zomb-edy."
Its refreshing conclusion is more suited to ambiguous European sensibilities than the all-American desire for happy endings or at least concrete resolutions ...
Despite its sluggish intervals, "Life of Crime" satisfies in the end, just when you fear it'll peter out.

It all dwindles into "Who cares" long before the end of the road.

It's more of a nouvelle-cuisine starter course than a square meal.

movie_review_blurb: An ethereal modern fable without a moral, Tony Takatani seeps into the soul and lingers. For filmgoers in search of a quietly absorbing escape, it might be the perfect holiday-movie antidote.

If Winslet carries the complex psychological intrigue of the film on her shoulders, David Kross carries the heart of it on his.
A must-see for political junkies of any nationality.
The film version's biggest challenge? The road to self-discovery is littered with clichés.
Thanks to star Emma Thompson's smart, appealing script, the mysterious babysitter with the grotesque face and no-nonsense ways once again delivers a welcome antidote to Disneyfied heroines.

"Bachelorette" commits only one crime, but it's a make-or-break offense -- it's just not quite funny enough.
A feast for fashion-history buffs and anyone who applauds unstoppable eccentricity.

movie_review_blurb: Clever dialogue can make up for one-dimensional characters, and amped-up action can disguise a thin plot. Here, we get too little of either.
It's the entertainment equivalent of a good roadside-diner meal. No big belly laughs, but quite a few chuckles. No catharsis, but some really sweet moments.
