78/52 is frustratingly unfocused and woefully incomplete, skirting one of the shower scene's most obvious-and arguably important-aspects.
Robinson gives us a proudly queer romance that's an absolute crowd pleaser, and easily one of the best films of the year.
To their credit, the cast tries to bring some life ...but a script with all the depth of a baby pool cannot be saved.
This epic is a case of too too much, in the bad way.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: From top to tails, it's a haunting and poignant film, alive with beauty, pain, and heart.
This gonzo genre mashup is extraordinarily entertaining, boasting a killer soundtrack, sparkling spirit, gruesome gore, and much, much more.
Haunters: The Art of the Scare is a poignant, spirited, and fun exploration of a curious corner of macabre entertainment.
movie_title: Haunters: The Art of the Scare (2017)

movie_review_blurb: I have seen into the abyss, and it has drained from me my very will to live. Which is to say, I have seen The Layover.
Who needs heroes when you have pseudo-intellectual hipster bullshit?
...Undeniably charming, although not especially ambitious in storytelling, animation or emotional stakes. But sometimes you just want a summer movie that'll make you laugh.
Though it possesses a mournful beauty, A Ghost Story is sullied by (Casey) Affleck's presence.
It's a momentous occasion for the director and sci-fi fans. It's a shame it's not a momentous movie.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Blending magic realism, pop art moxie, and humane storytelling, director Daigo Matsui delivers a dreamy feminist critique of modern Japanese culture.
movie_title: Haruko Azumi Is Missing (Japanese Girls Never Die)(Azumi Haruko wa yukue fumei) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Incredible Jessica James is pretty wonky, delivering a story that's heart is big, but that's path is meandering. Still, Williams makes it sing.
There's a special mix of outrageousness and obliviousness that Lowlife plays for laughs, and it pays off with big ones.
Witty, warm, and funny, Landline is a charming comedy, edged just a bit by its heartbreaks.
"Imagine if Jumanji and Cabin In The Woods had a blood-thirsty baby. But it's a baby, so it's still pretty stupid."
Death Note is a whitewashed, hasty, and vapid adaptation that offers one great performance, few thrills, and lots of missed opportunities.
Pork Pie offers a wondrous road trip comedy full of humor and heart, with a healthy dash of Kiwi sass.
What if you combined the premises of Bridesmaids and Bad Moms, but bled them dry of risque humor? This bland cocktail would be Fun Mom Dinner.
Watching the movie, you can't help but feel you've missed a key scene, a puzzle piece that'd make everything click together.
Ocean's Eleven meets The Breakfast Club in Bad Genius...This bitingly brilliant teen movie is deliciously clever and laugh-out-loud funny.
You've seen blood-sucking vampires, rampaging zombies, and sinister clowns. But have you ever seen these horror archetypes mashed up into one ludicrous yet menacing monster?
It aims to capitalize on our perverse fascination with the Milwaukee Cannibal, while congratulating ourselves for finding a moral message in his tragedy.
While the film's wonky tone made it an uneasy ride, Plaza drives with her eyes ever on the horizon.
Lithe, lively and ludicrous, Logan Lucky is a joyful celebration of Southern culture with a generous helping of down-home whimsy.
It's not fun. It's not frightening. It's just f*cked.
Santoalla is a true crime documentary unlike any you've seen before. It's nuanced, bittersweet, and haunting...
Not only offers a feast for your eyes, but also imagery so evocative it'll make your heart race and your fingers tingle with the memory of sun and touches from summers past.
My Little Pony: The Movie offers a sophisticated message about trauma and self-love.
For all its lovely locations, neat parallels, and winsome performances, it feels lightweight. It feels like kids' stuff.
Swift, sweet, and spirited, Saturday Church is a gem.
In The Polka King, Forbes amp up the lunacy, star power, and energy to create something not only sensationally fun, but also enticingly thought-provoking.
Though a brutal watch, I recommend Kangaroo. In 99 minutes, it swiftly acquaints international audiences with the complexity of this issue.
There's dark comedy, and then there's Efthimis Filippou.
Winchester shoots itself in the foot at every opportunity.
Don't trust the trailers. Peter Rabbit is great.
Black Panther is absolutely majestic.
There'll be blood, and fire, and guns, and an axe. But there won't be satisfaction.
Paddington 2 is a stellar comedy with smart setups, superb payoffs, and belly-rocking laughs. It's a thrilling and whimsical adventure that will have your heart soaring.
(Director Brian Crano) gives Permission a tremulous tone that's in turns sexy, tender, and heart-trembling.
As the credits rolled, I felt cheated, robbed of a climax that suited this sophisticated and deliciously dark comedy.
If you're looking for a rapturously funny film with a crackerjack cast, Game Night's a winner.
The underwhelming mystery at its center damns The Lodgers to mediocrity.
Portman is painfully restrained in the lead role, looking upon biological impossibilities and mutilated corpses with the same distant curiosity.
Mute feels like a dream: strange, amorphous, emotionally remote, and senseless.
This spy adventure is not a power fantasy for women, but a sexual fantasy for men who like to think they're feminist. (Spoilers: they aren't, and neither is Red Sparrow.)
There are times in our life where art saves us...Ava DuVernay's beautiful and gripping A Wrinkle In Time is that miracle.
Stumbles aside, Fantastic Beasts and Where To Find Them is enthralling, enchanting and joyful.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Bland, unsatisfying, and a waste of one really good element.
The film has a sharp and undeniable charm. Then Sorkin gambles away audience good will with a stupid, ham-fisted ice rink sequence.
Christopher Plummer scowls and brags and blusters...Frankly, I preferred his Scrooge in The Man Who Invented Christmas, where his theatricality was better suited.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This movie is boring, tone-deaf, and infuriating. But it does make an unexpected point about Damon's persona. (Though that was probably not Payne's intention.)
Lobdell's horror-comedy isn't scary or funny, boasting jump scares and jokes that might have felt fresh twenty years ago.
Goodbye Christopher Robin is a maudlin and frustrating film.
A shambles of a film, desperately straining to tie its fraying threads together, if not into an impressive tapestry or a tidy bow, then at least in a gnarly knot.
(It offers) a heady blend of love and pain that makes Rift feel like Call My By Your Name meets It Comes At Night.
Full of action, laughs, and spirited fun, Thor: Ragnarok is a fine Marvel movie. But lacking a heaving heart, it's a disappointing Waititi offering.
" a jarring combination that goes together as well as peanut butter and poison."
There's an easy yet unnerving authenticity in Lady Bird, making it feel like a welcoming yet soul-baring memoir.
This movie has a mean streak a mile wide... And on top of that, there's a overgenerous supply of juvenile and sexist nonsense.
This is a lethally dull and ugly movie that possesses all the suspense of a damp hand towel.
McDormand commands the screen and plays her audience like a fiddle, stroking our outrage, tugging at our heartstrings, and coaxing screams of reckless laughter.
With scenes careening into each other oblivious of momentum, tone or plot structure, it feels like a Frankenstein of a film.
With an impeccable ensemble, taut tension, striking cinematography and a resplendent emotional intelligence, this drama one not to be missed.
Darkest Hour is fine, but forgettable. You can feel the filmmaker's fear of failure in every bog-standard biopic scene.
Angelica feels like Alias Grace meets The Babadook.
Nalluri has delivered a delightful and touching holiday film just when we need it most.
Every frame is enchanting, bold in color, and flush with emotion, then made exquisite by Alexandre Desplat's Parisian-inspired score.
It's a good, reliable drama. It's also safe, predictable Oscar bait with nothing new to say.
What a poor time for the release of Paul Thomas Anderson's Phantom Thread, which pushes the narrative that geniuses are on some level allowed to be abusive.
"I laughed. I cried. I screamed and cheered so much that my throat went raw, and I left the theater on a high of exhilaration."

By thoughtfully considering how a modern Spider-Man would fit into the character-driven realm of the MCU, Watts not only created a superhero movie full of charm and surprises, but also one the best MCU movies yet.
Seamlessly blending human actors with CGI creatures and a wealth of visual effected violence, the film delivers awe-inspiring action. So why was I so bored?
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: I'd never thought I'd call a Brian Taylor movie "surprisingly tame". And yet here we are.
Coppola has brought together an exquisite ensemble that plays the drama like a tender and tense symphony.
The LEGO Batman Movie is perfect fun for Batman fans of any age or era.
Watching Oyelowo and Pike dance, flirt, then fall in love is glorious.
This outlandish and violent series is at its best when its fight scenes are both savage and inventive.
Regrettably, this groundbreaking co-production comes to less than the sum of its parts.
A Cure For Wellness offers far more style than substance.
Watching XX feels like falling into slippery nightmares, the kind that seem almost sweet as the daylight is breaking, yet leave you feeling shaken and unsure...
James Mangold has re-teamed with Jackman for an intense Western that re-introduces the brutish X-Men as a cowboy, wracked with remorse and reckoning with redemption.
Get Out is flat-out brilliant. Peele shows a rich knowledge of horror, and a sharp edge of humor that makes for a film that's frightening, fun, and impossible to forget.
It is cruel fate that planted Rings on a release date after we've learned that far scarier things can happen in seven days.
The standards for teens here are so low here that Before I Fall trips on them.
Condon took a star-studded cast, a dizzying budget, and a tale as old as time, and instead of manifesting a magical remake, delivers a lackluster re-enactment.
Beyond its unsettling intro, it steadily becomes a middling thriller.

"Win It All" might be Swanberg's most accessible film yet. The awkwardness and improvised feel often associated with mumblecore is passed over for a tone and dialogue style that's more polished, but no less impactful.
Drained of humor - dark or otherwise - this crime thriller becomes one note, and that note is bleak.
Movies like The Belko Experiment make me forget why I like horror.
Lowe has made a spectacular directorial debut in a film that is defiant, disturbing, and darkly hilarious.
Watch your back Heathers, because Tragedy Girls is coming to snatch your crown.
Colossal is a film so strange it's very existence seems a miracle.
Kong: Skull Island is a lively adventure that boasts bonkers battles and a wondrous wallop of star power from its humans and beasts alike.
It's a shame that this teen romance takes so painfully long to get to the heart of the matter.
It's the '80s rock musical with sex, mermaids, and murder you've been waiting for.
Raw, riveting and realistic, Killing Ground carves terror out of a simple setting by focusing on the plausible horror strangers can inflict on each other.
It's a thrilling adventure that surges with sensational songs, lovable heroes, and messages that promote responsibility, forgiveness, bravery and resilience.
This seems exactly the kind of "based on true events" tale that filmmakers go gaga for...The plotting lurches, bound by reality, making for a muddled though moving affair.
La La Land is cute, sometimes gorgeous, but not good.
Fences' performances are hands down some of the best of the year. But Washington...half-heartedly strove to make it cinematic.
Gordon and Speck make a lot of fumbles in the execution of Office Christmas Party.
Okja offers escapism with a generous dose of politics that makes it fascinating, funky, and fabulous.
If only the two-hour plus runtime made time to dig into its heroes like the original trilogy or The Force Awakens did, Rogue One could have been as sensational and satisfying.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Neither the heavy-handed expositional dialogue nor fire and late-in-the-day heroics can shake off the ick and sexist bulls--- of Passengers' disastrous second act.
With the Assassin's Creed games as inspiration, there was a rich mythos to pull from, but all this adaptation offers is muck and meh.
Much like Inside Out made the case for the value of sadness, A Monster Calls does the same for anger. And we need it.
Øvredal offers a more sophisticated and scarier story that pulls audiences to the edge of their seats, then pitches them back in genuine fright.
Scorsese takes a big gamble with the patience and faith of his audience.
Willfully meandering but undeniably engulfing.
Sure to speak to kids and grown-ups alike, Zooptopia unfolds a poignant lesson about how prejudice can hurt people, but also how it can be overcome. And it does all this in a wonderfully fun film.
Live By Night feels toothless even as blood sprays and bodies fall.
Unrepentantly absurd and unstoppably fun, Monster Trucks is exactly the kind of kids' movie I want to see from studios.
Sadly, even the foggy recollection of the original is better than this bloated bastardization.
Split feels rushed and careless, spectacularly bungling a premise that had potential.
This franchise resurrection is so overloaded with high-octane and absolutely insane stunts that it should require helmet.
Tapping less into emotions and more into adrenaline and wonder, it's more style than substance, but oh, what style!
Audiences will be helpless but to bow down, as Atomic Blonde has come to take your breathe away, and leave you giddy, gasping for more.
Hidden Figures is sensational, spirited and necessary. It reminds us not only where we've been, but how far we still have to go, and gives us signs of hope and direction.
The story Asensio spins is delicate and threatening, like a spider's web. The suspense woven through the third act is nauseating, and a bit sublime.
Be warned that Alien: Covenant is about 40 percent Alien, 50 percent Prometheus and 10 percent absolutely bonkers.
Ritchie's dizzying mismanagement of King Arthur: Legend of the Sword is the only spectacular thing about it.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: 3 Generations is well-intended and heart-warming, but a mess, and problematic besides.
Paint It Black is vibrant with emotion, and authentic in its journey, presenting an arc of grief that is raw, riveting, and surreally beautiful.
I absolutely loved this love story.
Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales suggests the time has come for this franchise to hang up its tricorne hat.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Gal Gadot has an adventure all her own - and all kinds of awesome - in Wonder Woman, a superheroine film brimming with majesty, action and heart.
Miscast and misdirected, Cruise can't conquer the towering monstrosity that is Kurtzman's ugly, senseless, and boring monster movie.
"Coogan is utterly exhausting as he grumbles one tirade after another about human nature, the value of history, and the importance of family loyalty."
In the end, I was left hungry for a payoff that never came, and lamenting that It Comes At Night's mood and nightmares are not enough to be satisfyingly scary.
Rough Night is an explosively funny, wonderfully wild, yet surprisingly smart sex-comedy that makes it perfect pick for date night or a girls night out.
The Book of Henry offers a despicable child hero, a ludicrous plot, and a cast of characters carved with all the delicacy of a chainsaw on a butter sculpture.
47 Meters Down is uniquely terrifying, offering an authentic exploration of a nightmare scenario, treating sharks as keen predators, but not evil villains.
It's this heady mix of vulnerability and self-aware wit that defines Career Suicide, making it mesmerizing and heartwarming.
It's cute, funny, and vulnerable, The rest of the world is finally catching up to crushing on Nanjiani and Gordon.
Those looking for some bang for their buck would be hard-pressed to do better, as Bay offers more bangs, bells, whistles and bonkers moments than any filmmaker working today.
The Bad Batch is challenging, unnerving, and even hilarious in whip-smart bursts.
Franco wants to have his cake and eat it too, openly mocking Wiseau for his weirdness, then heralding him for his persistence and ability to embrace The Room's reputation.
Cars 3 is a bit all over the road...But I'd advise just give in and enjoy the joyride, bumpy, bonkers and bittersweet as it is.
Bombshell becomes not just a stupendous tribute to Lamarr, but also a tribute to every brilliant woman ignored.
It chucks a bunch of f-bombs, dick jokes, and gross out gags, creating a crude comedy that's more often repulsive than fun.
Dog Years is a movie that strives for elegiac depth, but achieves only snoozy shallowness.
Free Fire is a fearless and sharp shoot 'em up, loaded with star power, and polished with gallows humor.
As a director, (Quinn Shephard) crafted a film that's moody, raw, enthralling, and haunting.
It might be inelegant, but it's nonetheless a solid equation to appease the nostalgic a new generation of fans.
Muppet Guys Talking boasts an easy vibrancy and radiant joy in this conversation that we feel lucky to be the fly on its wall.
movie_title: Muppet Guys Talking: Secrets Behind the Show the Whole World Watched (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The great irony of the film is that while its plot is all about the search for soul, Ghost In The Shell is all style, no soul - or, rather, all shell, no ghost.
Through painting a story that boasts both dizzying moments of drama and self-sacrificing heroism, Caro delivers not just a history lesson, but also a rallying cry.
Smurfs: The Lost Village undercuts its central plot by suggesting that Smurfette's identity isn't about her self-discoveries as much as how the male Smurfs perceive her.
This fantastic family drama is so alive with humor, spiked with human hurt, and glowing with charm that it's impossible to fault it for the occasional overzealousness.
While there are a few fantastic moments to relish in Fate of the Furious, it seems Gray doesn't really get what got people so excited about this franchise.
It's absolutely confounding that this movie is so, so very boring.
Hounds of Love is a terrifying edge-of-your-seat thriller...(with) a barbed psychological thread that pulls from such ripped-from-the-headlines horror a radiant string of hope and love.
Instead of a fiery romance, The Promise's love story manages only a low boil.
"So smug and ponderous that even the allure of 13 performances by Cate Blanchett couldn't spur me from a stupor of annoyance and boredom."
All in all, this is a strong and engaging drama from a promising director who dares to urge empathy for figures traditionally dehumanized. And the performances are stirring.
" The script falls flat and lets down an emerging actress who deserves better."
Get Me Roger Stone is absolutely informative about the smiling Slenderman lurking in the darkest corners of Republican politics for decades. And...gut-wrenchingly terrifying.
It's a shame that instead of conquering new worlds, Gunn concentrated his efforts on trying to make lightning strike twice.
The Circle is a movie that is emotionally dead, intellectually vapid, and otherwise just dull. It doesn't even have the decency to be so bad that its failing is amusing.
Director Jaime M. Dagg brews an atmosphere of restrained loves and swelling hurt that carries his slow-burn neo-Western with mesmerizing mood and dizzying emotion.
The slow building dread makes 1922 a movie experience that does its due diligence to fester, just like the body that resides at the center of Wilfred's shame.
For the most part, Mom and Dad isn't here to provide answers but to shock and awe - effectively doing so.
Tulip Fever is a pretty picture, and it effectively transports you back in time, but once you are there you'll be headed to the exit before you can even smell the tulips.
This is a necessary, albeit uncomfortable watch with harrowing performances.
The heart of the film is lost by formulaic tendencies and its overbearing insistence on being funny.
The skillfully obtuse Infinity Baby withdraws from a usual comic routine and commits to its outrageous nature wholeheartedly.
In his second turn as director and third as writer, S.Craig Zahler again hits us with a sharp script.
Bright is a film trying too hard, with an execution that leaves something to be desired.

The Commuter is a mystery with no real intrigue and a drama without enough substance to cement itself as one of Neeson's best. Amid the rubble there is an entertaining enough film to provide respite during the Winter blues, just don't expect too much.

As unsettling as it is, The Strange Ones is also provoking. When the credits roll, it resonates. It is uncertain what's going to happen next to Sam, or if he can ever truly leave his past behind, but we are left wondering.

In the end, Maze Runner: The Death Cure held up its bargain to entertain, while giving these characters a quality send-off. Not without its flaws, there is enough to appreciate if you're willing to look.

Permission creates a compelling case study of adult relationships. With the direction of Crano he gives us a romantic drama that provides us with a heavy dose of romance, but also focuses on its decline.
It seems that The Lodgers never quite meets its potential. This is the kind of film that has been done before, better, but that I believe keeps us optimistic for the future of those involved.
The script by John Whittington doesn't emphasize on the good enough to save the story from feeling limp. It isn't something you haven't seen, but it may entertain enough for a night in.

As a whole, Oh Lucy! is an inventive story that's remarkably relatable. What makes the sympathetic Setsuko so wonderfully charming is a combination of Atsuko Hirayanagi's story and direction and Shinobu Terajima's endearing performance.
What's frustrating is how Devil's Gate just grazes greatness in a couple areas, missing its mark.
It's another fanciful, joyously unbelievable, feel-good film about the orphaned mouse adopted by a loving human family.
Home doesn't sparkle enough to make the transition from kids film to modern classic... That said, Home is possibly the most cheerful alien-invasion-of-Earth film you're likely to see.

Insidious: Chapter 3 is unlikely to win over new fans to the franchise. It's a slow, jump-scare-ridden film with lazy callbacks to the far superior originals, lacking their visual flair and plot intricacies.
Minions is like a sugar rush -- short and sweet, but just a little shallow. Nevertheless, it's an anarchic bit of silliness for kids to enjoy.
It's not the most original premise, but has some solid performances and genuinely disturbing moments nonetheless.
ParaNorman is a fun and rather sweet film which will subtly delight pop culturists and which asks some gentle questions about human nature.

The Messenger feels listless. It never quite gets off the ground, and the characters come across as two-dimensional tropes rather than people worth investing in. It's a shame, because there's an interesting premise underneath it all.
Lives up to its huge hype with a spirited and well crafted story that could become actor-cum-producer Aamir Khan's magnum opus.
movie_title: Lagaan: Once Upon a Time in India (2001)

A professional piece of tech-thriller product, but clouded throughout by an air of insufficiency.
The story is a hash of beefcake mythology, the dialogue a steady dribble of earthbound utterance, the sword-clanging action a master class in un-excitement.
And yet, these movies are scary, the latest no less than its four predecessors.
Whatever the movie's flaws, it's a great Rabelaisian entertainment whose grimy pleasures can't be denied.
An enchanting tale of love among our many machines.
As serviceable as the plot is, it's the strafe-and-burn dialogue we've come to hear, and this is a bit of a letdown.
It may have "heartwarming holiday fare" all but engraved above its title, but it's entertainingly crafted holiday fare, and should warm the hearts of all but the grimmest cynics.
A wannabe Scorsese movie that could be left wallowing in the wake of an actual Scorsese movie-The Wolf of Wall Street-which opens on December 25th.
Further adventures of Bilbo and the dwarves Thorin, Balin, Bifur, Bofur, Bombur, Dopey, Sneezy, Grumpy - you remember.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Unflinchingly brutal and strikingly pointless.
Admirable in its parts. But as Coen brothers movies go, kind of minor.
The story remains a very nasty piece of work.
Even viewers dragged into it kicking and screaming are unlikely to be bored out of their minds. Well, not entirely.
The worst kind of bad movie -- it doesn't even offer the pleasure of simple, idiot fun.
Laced with real-life psychodrama, it holds your attention almost in spite of itself.
The movie is careful to avoid amusing us in any way, and it has the soft, gooey heart of a Hallmark valentine.
...so near-perfectly pitched, it transcends its genre.
A grand and magical picture that recalls the sense of wonder that movies could once awaken in us.
A juicily perverse Southern Gothic creepfest.
The CGI overload is way too much of a well-done thing -- the movie often feels like a wall-to-wall digital fabrication.
The movie is enriched by a number of famous actors-some of whom would have to be said to be slumming.
Tired, monotonous, and generally unnecessary."
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's stretch for happy-happy at the end can't wash away the sour taste of all that's come before.
A story that Hitchcock himself might well have wanted to tell.
What the Twilight films might have been if the Twilight films didn't, you know, suck.
It's not awful-certainly not as stupid as Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter. But that's a very low bar to clear.
The movie has a good skeezy kick, and its pleasures, however minor, can't be entirely written off.
A very stylish ghost story with more on its mind than the usual slash-and-bleed horror flick.
Due out last September, now turning up in the film-dump month of January. Where it seems right at home.
Haneke, a master of icy appraisal, here contemplates an elderly Parisian couple at the very end of their lives.
I have to admit that I was sometimes moved to the verge of contemplating the possibility of tears.
Korine's latest helping of dubious hipster bait...
Might be the most savage cinematic depiction of slavery ever made.
Achieves something rare, presenting a hot-button subject-torture-without the usual moral nudging.
Not what you might have been expecting, or hoping for.
Nicely balanced between savage violence and sweet human interactions, and it whips along at a brisk pace.
Deadfall has most of the elements of a good noir: sex, love, doom, death. But about halfway in you can tell that the film itself is doomed.
Talky noir with overbearing political agenda.
Alfred Hitchcock would probably be happy that he's finally getting his close-up, but I don't think he'd be thrilled about the way it's being framed.
More than just a rip-roaring boy's adventure. Much more, unfortunately.
It's tiresome to hear reviewers hyping this or that funny movie as "the year's best," so I won't. But you get the idea.
This sensitive new Bond world is really not enough.
With its ultra-bloody action and magical implausibilities, it drips authenticity.
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: For a movie so jammed full of stuff-nearly three hours' worth of it-Cloud Atlas feels oddly empty.
All wrong in just about every way.
Very creepy, and still very effective.
...blithely generic, but not...how to put it...entirely unentertaining.
The novels are a film franchise waiting to happen. Judging by this film, though, I'd say they'll have to wait a little longer.
Passes up any number of opportunities to be much funnier than it is.
The infuriating facts in this famous case are illuminated with new human detail.
Shaffer, an actual top-ranked high-school wrestler, may not be a professional actor, but that's almost certainly about to change.
Director Wan takes a new pass at the creaky genre and comes up with exactly what you'd expect.
Could almost be a parody of a bad art-house movie - except that it actually is one.
But could it follow After Earth and The Lone Ranger into the currently raging bonfire of box-office despair?
A sunny wonder that effortlessly out-classes such floundering box-office behemoths as The Lone Ranger and White House Down.
Whoever decided to revive the Lone Ranger would normally not be consulted for bright ideas again at any time in the near future.
Any movie that introduces its star in conversation with a squirrel would have to be going for comedy, you'd think.
A real surprise, from one sensational set-piece sequence to the next.
It's hard not to think, "What idiots."
It's like a sprawling mega-budget CGI movie about other sprawling mega-budget CGI movies.
Gut-wrenchingly funny...a giant ball of flaming self-mockery.
Fillion is the most lovable of big lugs (and possibly the first Shakespearean character ever to don shades).
The stars deserve better material than this -- and they shouldn't wait another eight years to find some.
Has an appealing comic spirit, and it's a considerable amount of fun, in parts.
A serviceable superhero exercise that does a number of things right.
Not since John Travolta kicked the tires on Battlefield Earth and pronounced it good to go has there been a big-name flameout as disastrous as this.
Achingly unfunny.
It's not often -- not ever, in fact -- that a movie will put you in mind of Battlefield Earth.
The picture plays out almost as ritual -- a dark, hypnotic experience.
This exercise in classical blood-bath monotony does its job, but little more.
Dreamland psycho-thriller elevates plot-knotting mind games to a delirious new level.
We feel a tide of boredom rising. But it's Terrence Malick, so we hang on.
Gripping -- filled with rich performances by a top ensemble cast and powered by a script that punches home its points with memorable detail.
Blanchett is all the reason anyone might need to see this movie.
A light sci-fi snack of gently pre-chewed elements from other, meatier futuristic movies.
McConaughey's resurgence is a glorious thing, and it continues with Mud.
There may be no such thing as "magic," but Ricky Jay's mastery of illusion really is magical.
movie_title: Deceptive Practice: The Mysteries and Mentors of Ricky Jay (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Surprisingly surprising...
Techno overkill is a big part of the movie's fun, and nothing overkills quite like IMAX.
The combination of high-level performance and subtle construction, in a picture in which nothing blows up, is actually thrilling.
Baffling from beginning to end, but also woozily beautiful.
There are more headshots in this picture than might be found at a SAG board meeting.
It says it all: naked broads on the moon. Of course it's going to be great...and bizarre as all get-out.
You should have been running to the video store before you got to this sentence.
This is the quintessencial psychotronic film and Russ Meyer's best.

The film could have devolved into another variation of Godard's galaxy in a coffee cup, but It's Such a Beautiful Day retains the biting humor and fecund observation of the everyday that allows it to stretch as far into the domestic/cosmic as it can.
Through its treatment of its franchise's history, the movie succeeds in some ways -- and crucially fails in others.

t's fun and mostly inoffensive, never taking itself too seriously while it rewards its inexplicable fans. Better still, it makes every effort to borrow from the Fast series' latter-day push for more diverse heroes.
Underneath this glossy veneer is a truly ugly core.
Adonis Creed is an American hero audiences could adore for a long time. He climbed the Rocky Steps right next to the Italian Stallion himself. What else is he capable of?
With its beautiful cinematography and a towering performance from Abraham Attah, Beasts of No Nation is a movie that demands attention and consideration.
Steve Jobs mostly succeeds, crafting a human portrait of a tech leader who struggled behind the scenes to be greater than his failings.
Its greatest achievement, though, is its refusal to let the viewer abide by the third rule of improv: don't think.
What remains are the bones of a decent genre flick, with the aspirations of a Nicolas Winding Refn film. Perhaps Aulakh will get there one day, but there are several kinks to smooth first.
It's hard not to feel a twinge of frustration.
movie_title: My Love, Don't Cross That River (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its melancholy, and at times upsetting subject matter, Moonlight is a film with a genuine, openhearted message: love survives. Surely the hardest of hearts would be moved by this beautiful film.

Personal Shopper can be categorized as a character study within the frame of an anti-horror flick, and character studies always demand patience. Those who are willing to meet Assayas halfway will find the film rewarding.
It remains an aesthetically filmed blend of off-beat comedy, mind-boggling sci-fi, and subjective storytelling that serves as a singular and timeless piece of cinema.
Your Name. is an engaging if saccharine universal tale of self-discovery. It's also a visual masterwork.

By the end credits, Nocturnal Animals feels well worth the ride, even if it runs out of track in its final few minutes. It's far from perfect, but also hardly needs to be in order to provide an intoxicating cinematic experience.
As both an origin story about a great artist and a distillation of '80s urban blight, it's as breathless and real as any street-corner rhyme.

Not even the buoyant, self-deprecating spirit that spills from the band members can mask the fact that Angio never makes the most fundamental case: why there should be a Mekons movie in the first place.
Kidman and Firth are both excellent in their sadness and savagery, and Joffe builds tension far better than most of the horror movies available at your local Cineplex this Halloween weekend.
Best left on the shelf.
It works neither as a sweeping historical epic nor as an action-horror hybrid.
For a superior experience, go buy a disturbing-looking doll that says ''Don't go see Annabelle'' when you pull its string.

The first half of the film merely treads water in anticipation for the eventual bloodbath, and once the teeth start gnawing, it's just one laborious machination after another to get to the end of the movie, which stops without much of a resolution.
The dancing is the star of any of these movies, and Sie knows when to get out of the way and let it do the heavy lifting.
Too-brief thrills only shine a harsher light on the film's laborious pacing and cringeworthy one-liners spilling from the maws of the ninja teens.
The abundance of his funky, inspirational music included in the film becomes numbing -- an unfortunate result for such a complicated, passionate pop figure.
Like much of Iglesias' material, the movie almost gets in your face before flashing a friendly smile and forgettably floating away.
Deliver devolves into a predictable, overlong waiting game. What's worse, it wants to convince you that it's a thoughtful meditation on faith ...
The Woman may be back for another fright, but Angel of Death doesn't haunt like it should.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Like other movies of its ilk, it's missing a very simple bit of next-level Hollywood technology: a tripod.
With the soulful Gleeson and a sweetly menacing Fassbender (under a giant helmet-head) at its center, the movie never loses its acerbic edge or its oversize heart.
Only Radcliffe escapes unscathed, lending Igor a convincing psychology despite the ham-fistedness of the material. But he's not enough of a reason to resurrect this story again.
Predestination's pace is too slack, and the brothers are so painfully tentative as storytellers that the easily guessed big twist gets three separate reveals.
It's the weakest of the trilogy, but Taken 3 kicks just hard enough to survive another day.
The only thing The Last Witch Hunter will successfully eradicate is insomnia.
It's hard to deny the hedonistic joy in the way Delamarre plays with his various toys, and the goofball stunts ... are generally worth wandering through the dialogue desert.
The movie is profoundly dumb.
Sinister 2 doesn't know what it wants to be, and doesn't add up to much.
SNL characters like Matt Foley will live forever, but Farley should be granted just as much credit for gamely carrying bad films on his broad shoulders.
The Perfect Guy escalates quite nicely, leading to a satisfyingly white-knuckled finale.

This is another found-footage movie that, with a little art direction and some actual cinematography, could easily have been a decent little terrorizer. Instead, it comes mostly unglued thanks to its hacky gimmick.
There's some chuckleworthy meta-commentary about the absurdity of sports movies, but Balls Out feels more like a long sketch than a feature.
Insidious Chapter 3 is the worst kind of sequel: Not terrible, but also cartoonishly unnecessary.
An admirable cat-and-mouse tale that puts forth a lot of clichés and executes them with B-movie intensity.
Chappie himself is lovingly and realistically rendered, though his personality shifts so often and so fast that it's hard to know how we should feel about him.
Hébert's terrifyingly electric performance keeps the heat turned up enough to make the bloody climax feel like relief.
Once the plot dominoes are arranged in an overlong series of setups, Seventh Son ends up being a movie about walking, interrupted occasionally by a battle against a mythological monster.

The Hateful Eight is not for everybody, but I found it completely compelling and engaging in a way that the first viewings of both Basterds and Django weren't. (They're currently my first and third favorite QT movies, for the record.)

I would certainly recommend the 80 minute journey. There's no subtitles, but you don't need them because all the dialogue is in an imaginary backward version of Portuguese. Just sit back and let the images wash over you.
movie_title: Boy and the World (O Menino e o Mundo) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Not for nothing, but John Williams' score is absolutely perfect as usual, and it makes every one of [the action] scenes come to life all the more.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: In the Heart of the Sea is a solid survival adventure story that never goes much beyond that.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: With Mockingjay - Part 2, however, we finally have a movie worthy of the hype.
This is a wholesome, heart string-tugging, tear-jerking story of perseverance. It's not as full as some of Pixar's others, but it's a really, really good movie.
The End of the Tour is one of the finest films of the year so far and one I hope as many people see as possible.
In the end, Experimenter feels a lot more like an avant garde play than it does a movie, but I think that's probably exactly what Michael Almereyda was going for.
So, I suppose, I would recommend this movie, provided you know exactly what you're getting yourself into.
Overall if feels like a high-concept approach to a very regular-concept story and doesn't land a lot of the time.
Ritchie and company have turned The Man from U.N.C.L.E. into a highly entertaining, immeasurably stylish, and thoroughly enjoyable movie.
The movie as a whole is good, not great, but Mikkelsen elevates it, as does Morgan who plays one of the better frothing Western villains we've seen in awhile.
The Nightmare is a completely singular work of documentary, unseen before to this degree of craftsmanship.

While this isn't a bad movie by any means, and will probably still delight most of the audience, I felt like it didn't quite have the spark of freshness that made the first Pitch Perfect so much fun. Enjoyable, but not aca-mazing.
Maggie is a father-daughter tragedy and one that's surprisingly effective, nuanced, and moving.
It's worth a look, though, just don't expect big scares or a particularly new plot.
Kill Me Three Times is a perfectly enjoyable, no-frills crime movie that benefits from a pretty though out-of-place location and some solid performances.
He Named Me Malala will certainly make you think while making you smile, and that's something any film can aspire to.
when the most notable thing about your movie is its continued reliance on recycled ideas and puerile stupidity, it doesn't make it destined for much else beyond a casual "Ha."
This is a marvel of bad editing and if that fascinates you, you might enjoy yourself; otherwise, I'd steer clear.

He's a character of a bygone age of literature and film plopped down into this time and place but with no realization that anything is different. All in all, you could certainly do a lot worse for a January release.
This movie is loathsome, that's what it is. I don't know why it exists. Don't see it.
You don't see a movie like this for the plot. Do yourself a favor and check this movie out at your earliest possible convenience.
Herzog narrates it himself and allows his own question-asking off-camera to be part of the film's narrative, and that personal touch is why it succeeds. W
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It is not much like the first one, but if you like a very well-designed and well-directed piece of dino-damaged cheese, then I think you'll have a good time. I certainly did.

The Martian is the kind of sci-fi movie I've been wanting for a long time-one where science takes center stage and the wondrous, awe-inspiring things that happen all stem from people solving problems using their brains, working collaboratively.

This is top-form James Bond and, amid all the other spy movies coming out this year (specifically Kingsman and Mission Impossible 5), it's good for 007 to reassert himself in such a firm and resounding way.
It's a movie that needs to be seen and experience for oneself. Then you'll probably want to call your mom, but be afraid to do so.
The effort into the sets, costumes, and cinematography are immaculate and everything is done for fun. Just don't expect Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon.
It's a fascinating, and troubling, two hours.
movie_title: Whitey: United States of America v. James J. Bulger (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Honeymoon is a gritty and disturbing horror movie that will leave you feeling the need to shower, never go into the woods again, and be wary of all lights in a seemingly-serene night sky.

Rosewater is a fine debut film and a very well told story of injustice and strength. It's not maybe as hard-hitting as it could be, but it's certainly worth looking for. Bahari's story is not as rare as you might think.
The best horror movie I've seen in a very, very long time.

If you're expecting another Seven or Zodiac or even The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo, you're probably going to be left cold, but if you go where the story takes you, and you buy into the world in any fashion, I think you're going to have a wicked good time
It's an engrossing, unsettling, and highly provocative film, and you certainly ought to see it if you get the opportunity.
You might enjoy the movie or you might think it's super boring. I liked it, ultimately.
While not breaking any new ground narratively, Son of a Gun is a solid prison-heist-escape movie with a truly terrific turn from Ewan McGregor.
I laughed a few times and despite some guy-a-mile-away plot moments, walked away feeling just fine about it. And from a jaded film snob, that's a very good sign.
Cut Bank is an entertaining enough movie with a good cast who mostly perform well. It just isn't the groundbreaking genre-buster its makers apparently think it is.
A movie worth checking out for the performances, but certainly not for anything else, unfortunately.
It exemplifies what Marvel has always done, which is make the superhuman more human.

To have a fun summer blockbuster with good characters, good action, and a tight and exciting script these days is almost unheard of. The smart sci-fi action movie is back. Let's hope it happens over and over again.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Guardians of the Galaxy is first-class, Grade-A space adventure comedy.
It's a thoroughly impressive piece of work and works on all narrative levels.
It could easily be shorter and no one would be mad, but personally, I thought it was a tonal improvement on the last film and actually made me care that I was watching a movie about Spider-Man.
Maybe after a long day of work and a big meal you can lie down on the sofa and be mildly bemused while you drift off. It certainly won't keep you awake through laughter.
We're left with a very lengthy first act, no second act of which to speak, and a rushed and incredibly unearned third act where our heroes have to band together using their new powers.
While maybe not as hard-hitting a drama as one might hope, Trumbo is a very engaging, very interesting, and very entertaining look at a man who for many years was a pariah.
By the Sea is little more than a passing notion, a suggestion of a film that ought to have been a lot better than it was.
Adults will absolutely find The Peanuts Movie delightful and charming, but the comedy and messages will still ring true for kids.
An intriguing and emotional journey with some fine performances all around.
Whether or not you care about Apple products or Steve Jobs, Gibney's documentary offers a story well worth watching.
movie_title: Steve Jobs: Man in the Machine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Overall, a much improved movie over the first, which I also enjoyed.

I wanted to really like this movie, but the laughs largely weren't there and the ultimate spiral of the movie attempted to rely on "shocking" dialogue and situations rather than actually pushing the envelope.
With the exception of a few genuine laughs, it feels very "old" and "la-may."
The Accountant a moderately effective action movie with good actors delivering a fun enough time, but it gets bogged down in lots of too-clever-by-half writing honey traps.
Shocking, eerie, doom-laden, and discomforting, it's a horror movie that truly gets under your skin.
As a total newcomer to the franchise, I was overall very captivated and charmed by One Piece Film: Gold.

Ultimately, despite some good scares, effective imagery, and good sense of tension, The Bye Bye Man doesn't explain nearly enough to make it all truly work, and for a movie with a concrete evil, we need some kind of lore to hang our hats on.
This is honestly one of the best comic book movies of all time.
It's certainly not a perfect movie, and a lot of the characters feel like sketches more than full fledged people, but it roars along enjoyably from start to finish.
A good, solid, scary sci-fi movie that knows exactly what it is but rises above it.
Still, the positives are incredibly positive and this franchise remains one of the most dumb-fun things you can hope to watch.

The action's great, the performances are top notch, and the soundtrack is killer. 2017's first Marvel movie is, impressively, one of the best sci-fi adventures you could hope to see. I defy anyone to watch this and not smile from beginning to end.
Tamblyn's work is incredibly self-assured for a first time director.
Going in to Alex Kurtzman's inaugural Dark Universe outing, The Mummy, I had a lot of excitement. Excitement that was quickly dashed.
Finally, with War, we see both sides becoming increasingly desperate, leading to an examination of which species truly is the most human. It's the absolute perfect end to this trilogy.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: I wish I could say that the performances didn't detract too much, but they sadly did. Even so, the visuals, action sequences, general storyline, and immersive experience of the 3D are enough to make me recommend people go see the movie.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's worth a watch, definitely, as it finally completes the Ghibli full picture, but anyone expecting a new Miyazaki movie will be left wanting.
[In This Corner of the World] is a beautiful slice of life that feels at once completely relatable and wholly alien, in the best possible way.
movie_title: In This Corner of the World (Kono sekai no katasumi ni) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: I'd certainly be happy with more Kingsman movies, because [Taron] Egerton is a winning leading man and [Matthew] Vaughn's action direction remains fantastic, but this movie feels like a victim of its unanticipated success.
Blade Runner 2049 supersedes its predecessor in a number of ways, and is not only a brilliant sci-fi movie, but one of the best movies of the year.
Gerald's Game is an excellent piece of cinema, and proves that story and performance can overcome even the most 'unfilmable' source material.
Goodbye Christopher Robin lives up to its rather bittersweet title, offering both a warm look at childhood and a reminder of how easy it is to grow up too fast.
This is top to bottom Hemsworth's movie, and in his fifth time playing Thor, is at his very peak, and that's quite the heroic feat.

After a decade of Marvel dunking on them, DC has given fans a brilliant Wonder Woman movie and a perfectly fine Justice League movie in one year, and that's the first step to a braver and bolder cinematic future.
Quibbles aside, Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is the perfect, light holiday family movie. You eat some popcorn, have some laughs, and go back to your own jungle.

It's not a perfect movie by any means; some of the comedy is a little too silly and one or two of the plot threads feel a bit less important than the others, but these quibbles were minor when compared to the parts that work. Those REALLY work.
[Hiromasa] Yonebayashi has crafted a stunning movie with genuine heart and humor, and one of the grumpiest cartoon cats you've ever seen.
This is smart, troubling science fiction, with a cast of supremely talented actresses, and [Natalie] Portman showing us a character full of turmoil bubbling under the surface.
Game Night steadily gaslights the audience by making them think they're watching a hardened dark comedy when what they're actually watching is a very sweet, very believable relationship comedy.
One of the best action films ever made.

Rogue One: A Star Wars Story succeeds far more than it doesn't, and has some rich characters and terrific performances (specifically Tudyk and Yen) to go along with the beautiful visuals and intense action.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Spider-Man: Homecoming is a soaring superhero adventure and is easily the best Spider-Man movie of them all.
I listened to the Stooges for a week straight following my viewing of Gimme Danger, and I'm guessing it'll do the same for you. Search out this movie... and destroy.

It's hard not to enjoy London Town for its mixture of bittersweet comedy-drama, excellent performances, and the use of several of the Clash's best songs of the era. A little bit of hokum in a rock & roll story isn't a bad thing at all.

The key to any good disaster movie is the setup, and the filmmakers do a very good job of making it feel real, of keeping the family's plight from feeling overwrought, and of establishing the danger as feeling imminent but not out of nowhere.
I didn't laugh at all -- I think I might have smiled once or twice -- because at its heart, the movie feels incredibly cynical and mean spirited about the sort of small town people it's depicting.
Go in with realistic expectations and you'll probably have a good time. After all, it's still a movie where man-gods punch each other.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: I would highly, highly recommend seeking it out if you can. It's a journey to a completely different version of Earth and a science fiction adventure that will still be timeless in a further 70 years
movie_title: April and the Extraordinary World (Avril et le monde truqué) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Ultimately, I really enjoyed A Hologram for the King, even if I don't think it fully explored the themes it was putting forth.
Not only is it another stellar Cap movie, it's maybe my favorite Tony Stark movie, and it also proves how you put a million heroes in the same movie effectively.

I think this movie is for fans of the franchise or characters only. While I could recommend Days of Future to sci-fi fans at large, I don't think there's much here for people who haven't seen the previous films or know the comics well.
The Lobster is an incredibly weird movie, but its heart is totally on its sleeve and in the right place.

While the story feels a bit more Hollywood, a bit less "real" this time around, the family drama is still right at the center and is quite effective, and there's just something so satisfying about Farmiga and Wilson as these two roving do-gooders.
I laughed consistently. It's a comedy; that's what you want.

For his latest, The Neon Demon, Refn veers into the territory of people like David Lynch with his story of how beauty, and the want for beauty, corrupts even the most innocent. Oh, and it's incredibly disturbing, in case you wondered.

I greatly enjoyed this movie, and while it veers toward the saccharine by the end, you feel like you've gone on the journey with Ben and the uniquely named children. The kind of journey we haven't seen before but wish we had.
I just can't help thinking the makers of this movie didn't realize Team America: World Police was a satire.
It's about putting in everything we know about Classic Hollywood in a single, hilarious package.
It does its job, you can watch it, laugh, and move on to hating something else before you've seen it.
It's very much a movie that feels made without narrative purpose.
Pete's Dragon is a satisfying and touching family adventure drama.
The tired old adage goes "truth is stranger than fiction," but in the case of Todd Phillips' War Dogs, the truth is more interesting than fiction, too.
Ultimately, despite the script's shortcomings, Imperium and its message and performances will stick with you, and you'll feel upset for a good long while after.
Sully is much more compelling than a regurgitation of everything you saw on the news.
Save a rushed and misguided sequel in 2000, the Blair Witch saga had all but ended... until fans of the original decided to bring it back, up the ante, and make a modern horror classic.
Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children is thoroughly enjoyable for the bulk of its run time, and Burton proves once again that he can do great things given the proper parameters.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: If you're expecting (or hoping for) the kind of Godzilla movie on the goofier side of things, you might be left wanting, but if you go in expecting a cool, refreshing take on the old paradigm, Shin Godzilla will be a hell of a fun time.
It's good for kids and has a good message about friendship and self-confidence. But it's far from the best in either Spielberg or Disney's long, illustrious catalogs.
If you enjoy westerns, and enjoy new riffs on the time-tested genre, it's a good, weird time.
[Nicholas Cage] works precisely because there is a great actor underneath it all and because he does tap into something so ferocious that other people wouldn't dare to touch.

Fortunately, Tanne didn't have to compromise at all with his two charismatic leads: Not only are they dead ringers for Barack and Michelle, but they go beyond impression to deliver something real and human-sized.
The best popcorn movie of the summer.
Writer-director Ben Coccio has made an intensely immediate, meticulously detailed bone-chiller -- it haunts you long after you've wished it would go away.
It's an experience, rather than another helping of the same old thing.

movie_review_blurb: Trier's intent is to reproduce a sweet, hazy vision of the agony of youth. Ever so elliptically, he succeeds.

movie_review_blurb: This film is headed quickly for DVD. In the video store, though, it isn't funny enough to be shelved in the comedy section nor dirty enough to be filed with the smut.
